body:
# 2024-03-18

Addressing the question [what connections are there between the Zettelkasten
system, creative ideation and network graphs?](../../it61). Trying to think
about how zk and graphs are complex systems, and how creative ideation is the
result of those systems. How does that happen? That [consciousness occurs when
colonies of cells are large enough in number and connections](../../k8pg) is an
interesting angle, but in the case of zk, the notes aren't 'interacting' with
themselves per se. Rather, it is the interaction within the mind, of the
information they hold, that somehow comes together to create an idea.

Idea's are generated from borrowing parts of pre-existing information.

body:
# 2024-04-02

The theories of [Connectionism](../../g/0d9n) (via
[Connectionism and Cognitive Architecture - A critical analysis](../../r/61ts))
and the 1-LS approach to interpreting networked data systems
([The Whole Is Always Smaller Than Its Parts - a Digital Test of Gabriel Tardes Monads](../../r/szz2)),
are seeming to fit my concept and approach to the
[ctech masters thesis](../../i/ip4r).

Connectionism will help to explain:

- how creative ideas can arise from zettelkasten (both are systems of data
  being input and output from nodes). Still to be explored is at what moment
  that happens in Zk: It happens when spawning a new note as well as when
  following a link to an established note. When travelling this way, the reader
  brings new context to the destination note, which is then infused with the
  content of that destination note and can lead to the unexpected discovery of
  'shared associations' (a term from Latour, the whole is always smaller... paper)

title: 2024-04-15: Angela zoom update (ANT)
lead: Questions:
body:
Questions:

Getting concerned about the practical work load:

- can I extend ZK instead of building the entire markdown parsing code? (yes)
- can I focus on AI features only? (yes)

- zooming in / out may be making the theoretical concept too broad
  - instead, concept could focus more on the ANT interaction between actors and
    translation; which can then have feature sets built from them.

When explaining Zettelkasten being a web of knowledge, she asked "what's the
difference between that and the internet?". This is an important question to
include in the thesis.

title: A sociology of monsters: Essays on power, technology and domination
link: [A sociology of monsters: Essays on power, technology and domination](r/2u38)
lead:
> p. 29 Two other kinds of multiplicity - multiple-personality and marginality.
> These "are the point of departure for feminist and interactionist analyses of
> power and technology."
body:
> p. 29 Two other kinds of multiplicity - multiple-personality and marginality.
> These "are the point of departure for feminist and interactionist analyses of
> power and technology."

> p. 31 Asking if technology and science are different. 

> p. 32 Science as an ideology becomes a complex authority for rationalisation,
> sexism, racism and other marginalisations.

> p. 33 "The purpose of this essay is to attempt to provide some tools hopefully
> useful for several of these discourses, and perhaps as well as show some ways
> in which technology re-illuminates some of the oldest problems in social
> science."

> p. 39 A cyborg is in a sense "the relationship between standardised
> technologies and local experience".

> p. 41 Once arrangements in a community become standardised, it becomes
> expensive or impossible to create an alternative standard. This is interesting
> in that it is true for both technological systems and societal systems.
---
> examining how standards are established in art and that the phenomenon is
> equally true for science and technology. 

> p. 42 Actor network theory and the mix between humans and non-humans involved
> in socio-economic systems.

> p. 43 Star argues against Latour's presentation of actor network theory
> stating that it breaks down boundaries that allow us to distinguish between
> humans and machines. 
---
> A good point that relates to marginalisation as well as Star's difficulty in
> restaurants accomodating his onion intolerance; "A stabalized network is only
> stable for some, and that is for those who are members of the community of
> practice who form/use/maintain it".

> p. 44 - 45 "In torture, it is in part the obsessive display of agency that
> permits on person's body to be translated into another person's voice, that
> allows real human pain to be converted into a regime's fiction of power."

> p. 46 Stories of men wanting to undergo transexual surgery, being required to
> dress and act as (stereotyped) women, and deny them surgery if they don't.

> p. 47 The world of the torturer/tortured are in fact so near to one another
> that our natural reaction is to avoid understanding or acknowledging it. But
> Scarry argues that it is precisely this distancing that is one of the factors
> that makes torture possible. 

> p. 48 "Stabilized networks seem to insist on annihilating our personal
> experience" This agin seems true for social media platforms. [social media
> platforms insist on annihilating our personal experience](../yys3)

> p 52 "Power is about whose metaphor brings worlds together, and holds them
> there."
---
> The essay is about "a point of departure for the analysis of power". In
> essence identifying places of transition between standards and non-standards,
> humans and machines, outside the building, in the building (transitioning
> through the door). This are spaces where power structures, metaphores,
> standards and expectations can become unhinged and lose their meaning. They
> hold no more structural power, and if we enforce that power in these spaces we
> lead ourselves into dark and uncontrolled places - torturing those who are by
> design of nature to inhabit these spaces. 

---
References:

- Star, Susan, and John Law. A Sociology of Monsters: Essays on Power,
  Technology and Domination. Sociological Review Monograph 38. London:
  Routledge, 1991.

title: ACCESS Approach
lead: Balancing Knowledge vs Action (y axis) and Folders vs Links (x axis)
body:
Balancing Knowledge vs Action (y axis) and Folders vs Links (x axis)

- Atlas : Meta view of knowledge
- Calendar :time based information
- Cards : considered notes
- Extra : support material (attachments, graphics, templates)
- Sources : outside sources of information
- Spaces : sections relating to you personally (usually Life and Work)

- each of these spaces has subfolders: mocs, areas, projects, support notes

2023-03-25: It never stuck. Don't try and implement other peoples ideas to the
way you order your stuff unless it really clicks. From the get go it was too
convenient that it was the acronym ACCESS... More marketing that usefulness. 

I address this in my [GRID system for Zettelkasten organisation](../ocul), and 
wrote about it [on my blog](https://tjex.net/blog/2024/zettelkasten-grid-system-organisation).

---
Reference:

- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0zWJ-TLghw
snippets: Balancing Knowledge vs Action (y axis) and Folders vs Links (x axis)

# ACCESS Approach

Balancing Knowledge vs Action (y axis) and Folders vs Links (x axis)

- Atlas : Meta view of knowledge
- Calendar :time based information
- Cards : considered notes
- Extra : support material (attachments, graphics, templates)
- Sources : outside sources of information
- Spaces : sections relating to you personally (usually Life and Work)

- each of these spaces has subfolders: mocs, areas, projects, support notes

2023-03-25: It never stuck. Don't try and implement other peoples ideas to the
way you order your stuff unless it really clicks. From the get go it was too
convenient that it was the acronym ACCESS... More marketing that usefulness. 

I address this in my [GRID system for Zettelkasten organisation](../ocul), and 
wrote about it [on my blog](https://tjex.net/blog/2024/zettelkasten-grid-system-organisation).

---
Reference:

- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0zWJ-TLghw

title: AI prompts can boost the creativity of writers, but result in similar stories
link: [AI prompts can boost the creativity of writers, but result in similar stories](r/w9tz)
lead: # AI prompts can boost the creativity of writers, but result in similar stories
body:
# AI prompts can boost the creativity of writers, but result in similar stories

AI doesn't help people who are already proficiently creative, but it helps those
who are not creatively skilled (obviously).

However, the end result are not better stories.

> ‚ÄúIt may be individually beneficial for you to use AI, but as a society if
> everyone used AI, we might all lose out on the diversity of unique ideas,‚Äù he
> said. ‚ÄúAnd, arguably, for creative endeavours we might sometimes need the
> ‚Äòwild‚Äô and ‚Äòunusual‚Äô ideas.‚Äù

If everyone used AI to create stories, we'd level the playing field and nothing
would stand out or be unique.
[AI is bound to mirror the collective unconscious of society](../z02o), and so
at this point, the collective unconscious would become very mundane and we'd
lose a lot of inspiration in our creative entertainments.

---

Source:
https://www.theguardian.com/technology/article/2024/jul/12/ai-prompts-can-boost-writers-creativity-but-result-in-similar-stories-study-finds

# AI prompts can boost the creativity of writers, but result in similar stories

AI doesn't help people who are already proficiently creative, but it helps those
who are not creatively skilled (obviously).

However, the end result are not better stories.

> ‚ÄúIt may be individually beneficial for you to use AI, but as a society if
> everyone used AI, we might all lose out on the diversity of unique ideas,‚Äù he
> said. ‚ÄúAnd, arguably, for creative endeavours we might sometimes need the
> ‚Äòwild‚Äô and ‚Äòunusual‚Äô ideas.‚Äù

If everyone used AI to create stories, we'd level the playing field and nothing
would stand out or be unique.
[AI is bound to mirror the collective unconscious of society](../z02o), and so
at this point, the collective unconscious would become very mundane and we'd
lose a lot of inspiration in our creative entertainments.

---

Source:
https://www.theguardian.com/technology/article/2024/jul/12/ai-prompts-can-boost-writers-creativity-but-result-in-similar-stories-study-finds

title: Academic Publishing
lead: ## Peer Review
body:
## Peer Review

1. Call for papers
2. Abstract submission
3. Preference, indications, conflicts
4. Paper submission
5. Paper distribution
6. Paper assignments
7. Review
8. Review overview
9. Check other reviews
10. Program committee meeting
    1. Rebuttal and/or revision
    2. Then cycles back to step 7.
11. Notifications
12. Camera-ready submission
13. Publication

# Academic Publishing

## Peer Review

1. Call for papers
2. Abstract submission
3. Preference, indications, conflicts
4. Paper submission
5. Paper distribution
6. Paper assignments
7. Review
8. Review overview
9. Check other reviews
10. Program committee meeting
    1. Rebuttal and/or revision
    2. Then cycles back to step 7.
11. Notifications
12. Camera-ready submission
13. Publication

# Academic papers are pretty much a distilled version of a thesis

Stay aware of this as it helps deal with the truth that academic papers do not need to be as encompassing and broad as your stress while writing may have you think!

title: Airy curtains in the European ether: Broadcasting and the Cold War
link: [Airy curtains in the European ether: Broadcasting and the Cold War](r/nlvd)
lead: Concepts: codification
body:
Concepts: codification 

Pirate radio broadcasting is looked at through the lens of Cold War tactics,
specifically the ambiguous line between propoganda and freedom of international
information. During the Cold War, the US in particular wanted to establish
broadcasting practices that stemmed the spread of Soviet ideals into the West.
Additionally they understood that this would destabilise the Eastern block. In
doing this, they were undergoing the same practices that the Soviet Union
employed - technically speaking. 

Pirate radios occupied a similar space in that they were seen as a threat to
established interests (commercial and national broadcasters). They operated
(initially) in unregulated waters, giving them the power to transmit and
broadcast how they would like. Laws were made to disable them, and it worked.
All pirate radio stations were eventually shut down.

The author establishes the idea that there was a paradox this process, as radio
stood for a national medium meant to unite a population, yet it was part of the
ethos that the listener should be able to learn and tune into the wider world.
Pirate radio therefore occupied the space in between. 

# Chapter: Between Rock and Roll and a Hard Place - Alexander Badenoch

> p. 1-2 It becomes "piracy" when actions cause offence to established
> interests. 

> p. 3 Modern day piracy doesn't threaten a specific sovereignty, but rather
> sovereignty itself. As was seen in the Cold War, it was a war to protect power
> and not national borders. 

> p. 4 Argues that pirate radio is not a radical break from European
> broadcasting history, but rather a continuation of dynamics that were already
> present. 

> p. 6 Radio embodied a paradox that it stood for a national medium meant to
> provide uniform coverage to unite a population, yet simultaneously allowed the
> listener to explore the wider world. This combination lead to the structuring
> of international agreements. 

> p. 7 The separation of frequency bands reduced interference at a receiver
> level, and political friction at a political level.

> p. 8 Listeners were also considered to be pirates after an amateur market of
> receivers and radio programmes threatened the BBC, who wanted to establish a
> monopoly on the radio market.  

> p. 9 After WW2, in 1947, the US moved to stem what they identified as the
> Soviet Union's influence moving through post war Europe - particularly in
> Berlin. They lobbied to have their US broadcasting frequencies allocated
> within Europe, as well as their frequencies from their occupied area of
> Berlin. This established the idea of international broadcasting (ie.
> broadcasting over national borders). This process didn't go so smoothly as
> noted in [Wormbs Negotiating the Radio Spectrum, ^fafa0c](capl).


> p. 11 - 12 The ship *Courier* broadcast the Voice of America, a radio
> initiative to distribute US values in an effort to reduce the spread of Soviet
> influence. It was therefore intended to create disruption within the Eastern
> Block, to disrupt the establishment, like music pirate radios. 

> p. 14 In reaction to VHF FM bands being introduced, which could travel
> further, radio broadcasters stated that listeners should only have the right
> to tune to their regional broadcasters.  

> p. 18 The "pirate era" dawned on August 2, 1958. Although it's not clear if
> the author means internationally - ie this was the first occurrence *ever*. 

> p. 19 It was the Nordic countries that led the way in putting together a
> strategy and legal framework to combat the pirates. 

> p. 21 The EBU recommended that broadcasters who were effected by pirate radio
> stations should engage in the same tactics seen today by monopolies.
> Specifically to make it illegal to aid the stations in any way shape or form,
> thereby starving creating extreme risk for those who were wanting to support
> or just earn money (eg in sales or repairs of equipment). Looks like it's
> heading towards [chickenization](../g/1uxv). 

> p. 29 The mobilisation of Cold War power is that of propoganda. ie
> broadcasting of ideas. Pirate radio embodied this to some degree. 

---
References:

- Badenoch, Alexander, Andreas Fickers, and Christian Henrich-Franke, eds. Airy
  Curtains in the European Ether: Broadcasting and the Cold War. 1. edition
  2013. Schriftenreihe Des Instituts F√ºr Europ√§ische Regionalforschungen, Band
  15. Baden-Baden: Nomos, 2013.
snippets: Concepts: codification
rawContent:

title: Automated Trouble: The Role of Algorithmic Selection in Harms on Social Media Platforms
link: [Automated Trouble: The Role of Algorithmic Selection in Harms on Social Media Platforms](r/cd8s)
lead: # Automated Trouble: The Role of Algorithmic Selection in Harms on Social Media Platforms
body:
# Automated Trouble: The Role of Algorithmic Selection in Harms on Social Media Platforms

###### p. 223

> Platforms stand accused of harming public discourse and democracy by fuelling
> social fragmentation, political bias, and polarisation, and by contributing to
> the spread of problematic content such as hate speech and disinformation
> (Persily & Tucker, 2020).


###### p. 225

Algorithmic selections can be manipulated by users for commercial or abusive
purposes.

While the algorithm can aggravate conflict, it can also be manipulated itself
for this exact purpose. For example, the German far-right group Reconquista
Germanica coordinated their members to post using the same hashtags on
Twitter at the same time. This manipulated the algorithm into attributing a
higher ranking for the hashtag. (Krei√üel et al., 2018). ^4db285


###### p.226

[the "Elsagate" controversy](../z391)saw nefarious content creators making
inappropriate content featuring popular children's cartoon characters. 


###### p. 227

Facebook offered a free VPN through their Onavo Protect app. While stating they
would keep user activity data private, they actually collected the data and used
it for competitive advantage over other companies. Highly related to
[Chokepoint Capitalism](jqzb).


###### p. 228

To some degree users can mitigate algorithmic harm with self action such as
privacy tools and switching to other providers. But this becomes increasingly
difficult if the control of technology slips out of our hands completely,
regulatory pressure does not increase, or both. It is a case for increased
open source development.


---
References:

- Saurwein, Florian, and Charlotte Spencer-Smith. ‚ÄúAutomated Trouble: The Role
  of Algorithmic Selection in Harms on Social Media Platforms.‚Äù Media and
  Communication 9, no. 4 (November 18, 2021): 222‚Äì33.
  https://doi.org/10.17645/mac.v9i4.4062.

title: Autonomous Creation of Musical Pattern from Types and Models in Live Coding
link: [Autonomous Creation of Musical Pattern from Types and Models in Live Coding](r/ci1d)
lead: # Autonomous Creation of Musical Pattern from Types and Models in Live Coding
body:
# Autonomous Creation of Musical Pattern from Types and Models in Live Coding

> p. 2 Live Coding is "a term used to refer to performers creating art by
> writing computer code, usually in front of an audience" (includes ref: Collins
> et al. 2003)

> p.3 TidalCycles stemmed from an artistic project dealing with machine
> learning algorithms, and was therefore designed to be straightforward to parse
> and manipulate for computers as well as humans.

> p.4 co-creative systems can have their creative potential defined through the
> interaction between a machine generating **novel** content, and the human user
> considering its **value**. 

> p. 6 Margaret Boden defines the notion of a "conceptual space"
> as a set of artefacts.

> p. 7 Flow diagram of components and processes used for sequence and code
> generation. Uses a n-gram model to create groupings of functions.

> p. 8 Autonomous pattern generation system explained.

> p. 10 Reduced bloat of generated code, by limiting function selection to
> functions that were unique, in that they had not yet been seen by the selector
> algorithm. 

---
References:

- Wilson, Elizabeth, Shawn Lawson, Alex McLean, and Jeremy Stewart. ‚ÄúAutonomous
  Creation of Musical Pattern from Types and Models in Live Coding,‚Äù 2021.
  https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Autonomous-Creation-of-Musical-Pattern-from-Types-Wilson-Lawson/dd9d40e6e7544914c1c22ac4d244aae8947204a6.

title: BERT - Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
link: [BERT - Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding](r/5gf1)
lead: # BERT - Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
body:
# BERT - Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding

The major limitation of major language model training is they are
unidirectional, which limits the choice of architectures that can be used during
pre-training.

BERT differs from pre-existing models such as sentence embeddings (word2vec),
paragraph embeddings (doc2vec) and ELMo as it has a bidirectional approach.

This means that it takes into account words before and after the current word.
This helps to capture the full context of a word in a sentence, leading to
better understanding and representation of small text documents compared to
unidirectional models that only consider preceding tokens.

BERT also incorporates a next sentence prediction task during pre-training,
which helps in understanding relationships between sentences. This capability is
particularly beneficial for tasks involving small text documents where context
and relationships are crucial.

BERT achieves bidirectionality by implementing a "masked language model"
pre-training objective:

> The masked language model randomly masks some of the tokens from the input,
> and the objective is to predict the original vocabulary id of the masked word
> based only on its context.

---

Source: Devlin, J., Chang, M-W., et al. (2019), BERT: Pre-training of Deep
Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding.

# BERT - Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding

The major limitation of major language model training is they are
unidirectional, which limits the choice of architectures that can be used during
pre-training.

BERT differs from pre-existing models such as sentence embeddings (word2vec),
paragraph embeddings (doc2vec) and ELMo as it has a bidirectional approach.

This means that it takes into account words before and after the current word.
This helps to capture the full context of a word in a sentence, leading to
better understanding and representation of small text documents compared to
unidirectional models that only consider preceding tokens.

BERT also incorporates a next sentence prediction task during pre-training,
which helps in understanding relationships between sentences. This capability is
particularly beneficial for tasks involving small text documents where context
and relationships are crucial.

BERT achieves bidirectionality by implementing a "masked language model"
pre-training objective:

> The masked language model randomly masks some of the tokens from the input,
> and the objective is to predict the original vocabulary id of the masked word
> based only on its context.

---

Source: Devlin, J., Chang, M-W., et al. (2019), BERT: Pre-training of Deep
Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding.

title: C++ Evolving a useful language - Bjarne Stroustrup
link: [C++ Evolving a useful language - Bjarne Stroustrup](r/9dpp)
lead: # C++ Evolving a useful language - Bjarne Stroustrup
body:
# C++ Evolving a useful language - Bjarne Stroustrup

Programming languages are tools. Tools for building interesting things. The
value of a language is the quality of the application.

~ 00:03:00

...

Build c++ in order to solve a problem; to build a distributed Unix.

~ 00:04:30

...

c++ rests on two pillars:

1. A direct map to hardware.
2. Zero-overhead abstraction in production code.

Built based on Simula (where classes and OOP originated from) and C.

~ 00:08:00

...

Programs require resources and release them when they're done with those
resources.

~ 00:14:00

...

Innovation isn't just thinking of a good idea. It needs development as well.
Therefore, innovation = invention + development.

~ 00:21:15

...

Fundamentals to learn, recommendations:

- a tour of c++
- Programming - Principles and Practice Using C++

~ 00:53:00

...



Bjarne started as a musician studying computer science. He was interested "in
the boundary between software and hardware". He found he had a problem in
investigating that, and for that he needed a language that didn't exist. This
became c++.

It's good to learn to program in investigation of a problem or interest.

~ 00:56:00

...

---

Source: Pitching and Peer Review Talk for CTech Masters, April 2024 via Zoom.
Recording:

[4:50](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEFcmfmdh2w&t=290) two main problems to syncing in general:  

*   unreliable ordering  
*   conflicts

[7:21](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEFcmfmdh2w&t=441) Solving unreliable ordering ‚Üí need to create and assign timestamps

[8:14](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEFcmfmdh2w&t=494) To solve unreliable ordering, we create reliable timestamps. To do this we need a reliable clock:  
  
*   vector clock  
*   hybrid logical clock (HLC)

[11:37](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEFcmfmdh2w&t=697) Solving conflicts: using CRDT‚Äôs

[15:32](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iEFcmfmdh2w&t=932) Grow only set. In distributed systems, you can never remove something from the set (your store of changes to local data)

title: China's billionairs looking to move their cash, and themselves, out
link: [China's billionairs looking to move their cash, and themselves, out](r/69d3)
lead:
[Xi Jinping](../g/d3gf) has spooked the ultra rich in China with his 2021 announcement of 
a need for [common prosperity](../g/6tak), which is almost like [Universal Basic Income](../g/09rb)
but sourcing the money directly from ultra rich private citizens.
body:
[Xi Jinping](../g/d3gf) has spooked the ultra rich in China with his 2021 announcement of 
a need for [common prosperity](../g/6tak), which is almost like [Universal Basic Income](../g/09rb)
but sourcing the money directly from ultra rich private citizens.

High US interest reates an weak yuan are a strong incentive for rich Chinese 
people to move their money out of the country.

$19.5 billion shortfall in China's balance sheet in the first half of 2023.
This indicates 'capital flight'.

What kind of effect will this have on China's economy. It will slow it for sure, 
but will it also increase entrepreneurship, as the up and coming companies will 
face less direct internal competition. 

---
References:

- [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/31/chinas-billionaires-looking-to-move-their-cash-and-themselves-out)

# China's billionairs looking to move their cash, and themselves, out

[Xi Jinping](../g/d3gf) has spooked the ultra rich in China with his 2021 announcement of 
a need for [common prosperity](../g/6tak), which is almost like [Universal Basic Income](../g/09rb)
but sourcing the money directly from ultra rich private citizens.

High US interest reates an weak yuan are a strong incentive for rich Chinese 
people to move their money out of the country.

$19.5 billion shortfall in China's balance sheet in the first half of 2023.
This indicates 'capital flight'.

What kind of effect will this have on China's economy. It will slow it for sure, 
but will it also increase entrepreneurship, as the up and coming companies will 
face less direct internal competition. 

---
References:

- [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/31/chinas-billionaires-looking-to-move-their-cash-and-themselves-out)

title: Chronotype
lead:
> _Chronotype is the natural inclination of your body to sleep at a certain
> time, or what most people understand as being an early bird versus a night
> owl. In addition to regulating sleep and wake times,
> [chronotype1](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28636610/) has an influence on
> appetite, exercise, and core body temperature. It is responsible for the fact
> that you feel more alert at certain periods of the day and sleepier at
> others._ Scientists consider it very difficult or impossible to purposely
> change your chronotype, though it may shift throughout the course of your
> life. - [sleepfoundation.org](https://www.sleepfoundation.org/how-sleep-works/chronotypes)
body:
> _Chronotype is the natural inclination of your body to sleep at a certain
> time, or what most people understand as being an early bird versus a night
> owl. In addition to regulating sleep and wake times,
> [chronotype1](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28636610/) has an influence on
> appetite, exercise, and core body temperature. It is responsible for the fact
> that you feel more alert at certain periods of the day and sleepier at
> others._ Scientists consider it very difficult or impossible to purposely
> change your chronotype, though it may shift throughout the course of your
> life. - [sleepfoundation.org](https://www.sleepfoundation.org/how-sleep-works/chronotypes)


Technique to find your Chronotype:

Think about what time you prefer to wake up on a day that you are completely
free to plan, with no work or other requirements.

# Chronotype

> _Chronotype is the natural inclination of your body to sleep at a certain
> time, or what most people understand as being an early bird versus a night
> owl. In addition to regulating sleep and wake times,
> [chronotype1](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28636610/) has an influence on
> appetite, exercise, and core body temperature. It is responsible for the fact
> that you feel more alert at certain periods of the day and sleepier at
> others._ Scientists consider it very difficult or impossible to purposely
> change your chronotype, though it may shift throughout the course of your
> life. - [sleepfoundation.org](https://www.sleepfoundation.org/how-sleep-works/chronotypes)


Technique to find your Chronotype:

Think about what time you prefer to wake up on a day that you are completely
free to plan, with no work or other requirements.

title: Container Deployment
lead:
Containers are similar to virtual machines but they have relaxed isolation
properties with regards to sharing the OS among other applications. Therefore
they're considered *light weight*. Similar to VM's, containers have their own
filesystem, share of the CPU, memory, etc. As they are decoupled from the
underlying computer infrastructure, they are **portable across clouds and OS
distributions**
body:
Containers are similar to virtual machines but they have relaxed isolation
properties with regards to sharing the OS among other applications. Therefore
they're considered *light weight*. Similar to VM's, containers have their own
filesystem, share of the CPU, memory, etc. As they are decoupled from the
underlying computer infrastructure, they are **portable across clouds and OS
distributions**

Extra benefits of containers ([source](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/what-is-kubernetes/))

- Agile application creation and deployment: increased ease and efficiency of
  container image creation compared to VM image use.
- Continuous development, integration, and deployment: provides for reliable and
  frequent container image build and deployment with quick and efficient
  rollbacks (due to image immutability).
- Dev and Ops separation of concerns: create application container images at
  build/release time rather than deployment time, thereby decoupling
  applications from infrastructure.
- Observability: not only surfaces OS-level information and metrics, but also
  application health and other signals.
- Environmental consistency across development, testing, and production: Runs
  the same on a laptop as it does in the cloud.
- Cloud and OS distribution portability: Runs on Ubuntu, RHEL, CoreOS,
  on-premises, on major public clouds, and anywhere else.
- Application-centric management: Raises the level of abstraction from running
  an OS on virtual hardware to running an application on an OS using logical
  resources.
- Loosely coupled, distributed, elastic, liberated micro-services: applications
  are broken into smaller, independent pieces and can be deployed and managed
  dynamically ‚Äì not a monolithic stack running on one big single-purpose
  machine.
- Resource isolation: predictable application performance.
- Resource utilization: high efficiency and density.
snippets:
Containers are similar to virtual machines but they have relaxed isolation
properties with regards to sharing the OS among other applications. Therefore
they're considered *light weight*. Similar to VM's, containers have their own
filesystem, share of the CPU, memory, etc. As they are decoupled from the
underlying computer infrastructure, they are **portable across clouds and OS
distributions**
rawContent:
---
date: 2022-07-26 09:28
tags: [glossary]
---

# Container Deployment

Containers are similar to virtual machines but they have relaxed isolation
properties with regards to sharing the OS among other applications. Therefore
they're considered *light weight*. Similar to VM's, containers have their own
filesystem, share of the CPU, memory, etc. As they are decoupled from the
underlying computer infrastructure, they are **portable across clouds and OS
distributions**

Extra benefits of containers ([source](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/what-is-kubernetes/))

- Agile application creation and deployment: increased ease and efficiency of
  container image creation compared to VM image use.
- Continuous development, integration, and deployment: provides for reliable and
  frequent container image build and deployment with quick and efficient
  rollbacks (due to image immutability).
- Dev and Ops separation of concerns: create application container images at
  build/release time rather than deployment time, thereby decoupling
  applications from infrastructure.
- Observability: not only surfaces OS-level information and metrics, but also
  application health and other signals.
- Environmental consistency across development, testing, and production: Runs
  the same on a laptop as it does in the cloud.
- Cloud and OS distribution portability: Runs on Ubuntu, RHEL, CoreOS,
  on-premises, on major public clouds, and anywhere else.
- Application-centric management: Raises the level of abstraction from running
  an OS on virtual hardware to running an application on an OS using logical
  resources.
- Loosely coupled, distributed, elastic, liberated micro-services: applications
  are broken into smaller, independent pieces and can be deployed and managed
  dynamically ‚Äì not a monolithic stack running on one big single-purpose
  machine.
- Resource isolation: predictable application performance.
- Resource utilization: high efficiency and density.

title: Conversations - Love and family and Asperger's
lead: # Conversations - Love and family and Asperger's
body:
# Conversations - Love and family and Asperger's

Tony Attwood is one of the world's leading experts on Asperger's Syndrome.
Attwood refers to people with Asperger's can be referred to as "Aspis".

---

Aspis are often not integrated socially, and will therefore take lessons in
romance and romantic behaviour from film and tv. This leads them to be clich√© or
not know how to handle specific situations.

~ 03:30

...

Dating and flirting for women Aspis can be particularly dangerous, because they
pay more attention to what's said, rather than what's intended (reading
underlying motive) through body language.

~ 05:00

...

Aspis are looking for someone to replace mum.

They ask, "who do I need?"

~ 11:00

...

If you live with an Aspi, you become and Aspi out of a need to adapt and survive
in the environment.

~ 19:00

...

Aspis have the ability to embody emotion in music and art, but can't express it
directly themselves through verbal or physical communication.

~ 22:00

...

Asperger's has been known as simply being "male behaviour" for previous
generations.

~ 33:00

...

The effort of managing and working on the relationship, overwhelmingly falls on
the non Aspi person in the partnership

~ 44:00

...

---

Source:
https://www.abc.net.au/listen/programs/conversations/tony-attwood-love-rpt/10304760

It was formed in 1995 when Deutsche Bundespost, a state monopoly at the time, was privatized. title: Developing Platform Economies
lead:
> p. 6 Call for more scrutiny of the digital platform economics that large
> corporations instil in the digital markets. Introduce the term "platformism"
body:
> p. 6 Call for more scrutiny of the digital platform economics that large
> corporations instil in the digital markets. Introduce the term "platformism" 

> p. 8 A need to address the implementation of AI within the sphere of consumer
> products and applications, bringing particular attention to themes of
> fairness, accountability and transparency. 

> p. 9 Trust is a "perishable commodity" and should be treated as an important
> bottleneck. For this we need to develop "trust infrastructure". 

> p. 10 Platform business models are generally intended to generate revenue by
> bringing together two or more separate groups and therefore making
> connections between markets. These connections are then sold. 

> p. 11 Schwarz is over optimistic that platforms will not exploit their
> position as key coordinators of market activities. 

> p. 11 Gy√≥di analyses an "extensive dataset" mapping Airbnb listings and
> assess the market effects of different regulatory approaches established in
> London, Paris, Los Angeles and New York. 

> p. 11-12 Findings show that stronger regulatory environments lead to a
> reduction in capitalistic business attitudes amongst Airbnb vendors - no
> surprise here. The idea here though is to highlight that the sharing economy
> is also susceptible and controllable to regulatory engagement. 

> p. 13 The digital landscape of China is examined, with attention given to the
> themes of an authoritarian government and monopolistic platform companies.
> Additionally comparisons between open source and proprietary software is
> looked at. 

> p. 14 Scaled platform companies need to be held accountable for their content
> and we need to develop ways to balance size against innovation. 

---
References:

- Larsson, Stefan, and Jonas Schwarz. ‚ÄúDeveloping Platform Economies,‚Äù 2018.
https://fores.se/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Developing-Platform-Economies_WEB.pdf.
snippets:
> p. 6 Call for more scrutiny of the digital platform economics that large
> corporations instil in the digital markets. Introduce the term "platformism"

> p. 6 Call for more scrutiny of the digital platform economics that large
> corporations instil in the digital markets. Introduce the term "platformism" 

> p. 8 A need to address the implementation of AI within the sphere of consumer
> products and applications, bringing particular attention to themes of
> fairness, accountability and transparency. 

> p. 9 Trust is a "perishable commodity" and should be treated as an important
> bottleneck. For this we need to develop "trust infrastructure". 

> p. 10 Platform business models are generally intended to generate revenue by
> bringing together two or more separate groups and therefore making
> connections between markets. These connections are then sold. 

> p. 11 Schwarz is over optimistic that platforms will not exploit their
> position as key coordinators of market activities. 

> p. 11 Gy√≥di analyses an "extensive dataset" mapping Airbnb listings and
> assess the market effects of different regulatory approaches established in
> London, Paris, Los Angeles and New York. 

> p. 11-12 Findings show that stronger regulatory environments lead to a
> reduction in capitalistic business attitudes amongst Airbnb vendors - no
> surprise here. The idea here though is to highlight that the sharing economy
> is also susceptible and controllable to regulatory engagement. 

> p. 13 The digital landscape of China is examined, with attention given to the
> themes of an authoritarian government and monopolistic platform companies.
> Additionally comparisons between open source and proprietary software is
> looked at. 

> p. 14 Scaled platform companies need to be held accountable for their content
> and we need to develop ways to balance size against innovation.

> *[marcosDigitalArtWhen2007a](zotero://select/items/@marcosDigitalArtWhen2007a), p.  98*  üü°

> "*The creative platform is the collection of infrastructures, tools, and technologies that enables the generation of artistic and cultural heritage content and the storage, transmission, and exchange of digital data.*"

> Constraints of digital artwork applications for proposed creative design space:

> - mobility: necessary or not (including for storage pre/post/during exhibition)
> - single / multiuser applications: consider the amount of intended users
> - user experience: previous user experience level with hardware / apps / interaction
> - addressees: target groups

title: Digital Ventriloquism - Giving Voice to Everyday Objects
link: [Digital Ventriloquism - Giving Voice to Everyday Objects](r/i6x7)
lead: # Digital Ventriloquism - Giving Voice to Everyday Objects
body:
# Digital Ventriloquism - Giving Voice to Everyday Objects

A research project and prototype exploring the propogation of sound, onto other objects in
the physical environment. 

The speaker emits a 40k frequency soundwave, that becomes audible when making contact with
a physical object. In this way, one speaker can assist in the illusion that multiple
objects in the room can emit sound on their own.

Useful applications for this would be augmented reality and people with poor or no eyesight.

---
References:

- [project page](https://www.chrisharrison.net/index.php/Research/DigitalVentriloquism)

title: Helium Network
lead:
[Helium](https://www.helium.com/) allows users to setup their own wireless hub,
that extends their own internet connection. The range is incredibly far and can
be extended with more hubs.   Users earn Helium crypto tokens based on how much
their hubs are used.
body:
[Helium](https://www.helium.com/) allows users to setup their own wireless hub,
that extends their own internet connection. The range is incredibly far and can
be extended with more hubs.   Users earn Helium crypto tokens based on how much
their hubs are used.

It's an interesting model in that there is user incentive to create a
decentralised network. The problem is the potential security risks - as the
network will connect via your own internet - and also be shared by other hubs.
As well as this, the ISP's will not like this at all - as you are sharing your
own internet connection and making money from it. 

It's also a technology that should transition well with the IOT era as well as
extended reality, in that users in local networks will have
very high speed connection to one another. Like P2P file sharing, but in
connectivity and communication. 

In [Coding Democracy](../r/tvng), decentralised internet networks and local internet
networks are also talked about.

## Functionality 

The helium network (from what I understand) is a network functioning with the
[LoRa](0cbi) protocol, which offers wireless capabilities that far out perform wifi
and radio. It's a large part of what will make [IoT](4izc) a functional
reality.
snippets:
[Helium](https://www.helium.com/) allows users to setup their own wireless hub,
that extends their own internet connection. The range is incredibly far and can
be extended with more hubs.   Users earn Helium crypto tokens based on how much
their hubs are used.
rawContent:
---
date: 2023-10-12
tags: [glossary]
---
# Helium Network

[Helium](https://www.helium.com/) allows users to setup their own wireless hub,
that extends their own internet connection. The range is incredibly far and can
be extended with more hubs.   Users earn Helium crypto tokens based on how much
their hubs are used.

It's an interesting model in that there is user incentive to create a
decentralised network. The problem is the potential security risks - as the
network will connect via your own internet - and also be shared by other hubs.
As well as this, the ISP's will not like this at all - as you are sharing your
own internet connection and making money from it. 

It's also a technology that should transition well with the IOT era as well as
extended reality, in that users in local networks will have
very high speed connection to one another. Like P2P file sharing, but in
connectivity and communication. 

In [Coding Democracy](../r/tvng), decentralised internet networks and local internet
networks are also talked about.

## Functionality 

The helium network (from what I understand) is a network functioning with the
[LoRa](0cbi) protocol, which offers wireless capabilities that far out perform wifi
and radio. It's a large part of what will make [IoT](4izc) a functional
reality.

title: How Tor Works
lead: https://www.youtube.com/embed/QRYzre4bf7I
body:
https://www.youtube.com/embed/QRYzre4bf7I

Multiple encryption layers. 
Ecah router has a key that can encrypt one layer of a message. 
Therefore each router only knows three things:
1. The router before
2. The router aftarwards
3. The encryption key for a singular layer

At the very last stage, a router decrypts the final layer revealing the real message (a server request). 

The reverse process happens on the way back: 
Each router encrypts the original message layer upon layer until it gets back to the user. 
The user holds all encryption keys and can decrypt all layers at once. 

The privacy therefore occures by the fact that there are many differnt 'hops' or routers between client and server and each of these router hops are encrypted. 
Therefore, even if someone managed to intercept the message a long the way, they would have no way to decrypt the message, and therefore do not have a way to identify the original sender.
snippets: https://www.youtube.com/embed/QRYzre4bf7I
rawContent:
---
date: 2022-11-22
tags: [video, clip]
---

# How Tor Works

https://www.youtube.com/embed/QRYzre4bf7I

Multiple encryption layers. 
Ecah router has a key that can encrypt one layer of a message. 
Therefore each router only knows three things:
1. The router before
2. The router aftarwards
3. The encryption key for a singular layer

At the very last stage, a router decrypts the final layer revealing the real message (a server request). 

The reverse process happens on the way back: 
Each router encrypts the original message layer upon layer until it gets back to the user. 
The user holds all encryption keys and can decrypt all layers at once. 

The privacy therefore occures by the fact that there are many differnt 'hops' or routers between client and server and each of these router hops are encrypted. 
Therefore, even if someone managed to intercept the message a long the way, they would have no way to decrypt the message, and therefore do not have a way to identify the original sender.

title: How much GUI is too much GUI?
link: [How much GUI is too much GUI?](3dqf)
lead:
I've been hearing that GUI elements use cognitive resources to process, and that
this reduces the bandwidth to focus / think. This makes sense and can be
supported by social media designers hijacking our cognitive functionality by
picking the perfect shade of red to trigger built in alert processes in our
minds.
body:
I've been hearing that GUI elements use cognitive resources to process, and that
this reduces the bandwidth to focus / think. This makes sense and can be
supported by social media designers hijacking our cognitive functionality by
picking the perfect shade of red to trigger built in alert processes in our
minds.

But how much GUI is too much GUI? This question has been excited while
setting up neovim. I have the choice often of including devicons or not, and
I noticed that with nvim-tree, having icons to denote every different file type
/ folder was actually distracting me from the raw information of what they were.

In other words, the coloring of the text and the extension allowed me to
identify and move through directory structures faster and with less
distraction. Or, the lack of icons did not make identifying files / folders
faster, smoother or easier - in fact it was a bit distracting.

Then, [reduce cognitive overhead to increase cognitive freedom](0yot).

An exception to this was the symbol for git file statuses and symlinked files
(little arrow). To me this suggests that files should only have symbols if their
context has shifted.

This idea of reducing distraction and therefore coginitive friction when
working, is the fundament behind [my Zettelkasten system design](/ocul).  

---

---

---

# How much GUI is too much GUI?

I've been hearing that GUI elements use cognitive resources to process, and that
this reduces the bandwidth to focus / think. This makes sense and can be
supported by social media designers hijacking our cognitive functionality by
picking the perfect shade of red to trigger built in alert processes in our
minds.

But how much GUI is too much GUI? This question has been excited while
setting up neovim. I have the choice often of including devicons or not, and
I noticed that with nvim-tree, having icons to denote every different file type
/ folder was actually distracting me from the raw information of what they were.

In other words, the coloring of the text and the extension allowed me to
identify and move through directory structures faster and with less
distraction. Or, the lack of icons did not make identifying files / folders
faster, smoother or easier - in fact it was a bit distracting.

Then, [reduce cognitive overhead to increase cognitive freedom](0yot).

An exception to this was the symbol for git file statuses and symlinked files
(little arrow). To me this suggests that files should only have symbols if their
context has shifted.

This idea of reducing distraction and therefore coginitive friction when
working, is the fundament behind [my Zettelkasten system design](/ocul).  

---

# Interactive Robotic Worm


Really creative and striking use of robotics. It uses a motion camera to
aggregate the position of people entering the museum. With this data it moves
and orientates itself towards them in a very cute and inquisitive way.

title: Internet governance by social media platforms
lead:
By controlling the flow of digital communication within this garden, social
media platforms are exerting governance.
body:
By controlling the flow of digital communication within this garden, social
media platforms are exerting governance.

Three thematic areas are focussed on: anonymity and privacy, freedom of speech
and restrictiveness of the platforms' interoperability with other technologies.
Through these themes, platforms attain very strong governmental abilities. They
can counter competitive advantage, remove or block accounts, adhere or decline
the requests of national governments and control how users interact with their
product through different hardware. e.g intentionally making their browser
version of the app terrible to use - thereby navigating around the privacy
constraints of some browsers. Instagram does not let you upload photos via the
computer and google maps performs terribly on mobile browser.

> p. 1 Addresses governance by social media rather than governance of social
> media. Specifically, the article examines the extent to which these platforms
> promote or constrain rights in three thematic areas: anonymity and privacy;
> freedom of speech; and restrictiveness of the platform's interoperability with
> other services and technologies.

> p. 1 The technical infrastructure of the internet is of significant public
> interest implications. The design and administration of this infrastructure is
> commonly referred to as "internet governance"

> p. 2 Looking at the conflicting themes of simultaneous governmental regulation
> and usage of social media, that platforms serve as a type of "privatised
> governance" for the public (potentially leading to dissent).

> p. 2 Governments embed political values in the design and operation of
> internet infrastructures and technologies by way of co-opting the various
> internet governance organisations. This is increasingly done for purposes
> irrelevant to the primary function of internet governance - to keep the
> internet functioning as a sound and unopinionated technical system.

> p. 3 Private companies are taking an increasingly central role in regulating
> civil liberties through the "ongoing privatisation of internet
> governance". This ties in with [The helping hand: In Search of a Swedish
> Institutional Regime for Infrastructural Systems](s2ly), whereby Kaijser shows
> how it has been seen that private intermediaries are given the responsibility
> of managing sections of infrastructure and that this can lead to issues down
> the line.

> p. 4 Interesting cases for why a real name identification policy online can be
> dangerous or impinge on the user's basic rights.

> p. 5 The "privatisation of privacy governance": whether anonymity is
> permissible, what information is collected about users, and how this
> information is shared with third parties.

> p. 6 The Communication Decency Act provides immunity for social media
> platforms against content posted by their users.

> p. 7 The government is constantly requesting social media platforms to remove
> or block content and accounts. Despite this, social media platforms comply
> with a small percentage of requests from the government, showing the power
> these companies do in fact have with regards to controlling content. Social
> media companies release these figures in their Transparency Reports

> p. 8 Platforms often behave like gatekeepers and constrain their users - eg
> maintaining competitive advantage by blocking rival products.
>
> We saw this recently with Musk blocking links to Mastodon.
>
> The disclosure of NSA's mass surveillance incited a greater interest for
> privacy, encryption and routing internet traffic around US servers.
>
> Social media platforms have eroded the interoperability of the internet by
> establishing such great market share, but developing propriatorey API's that
> relate only to their service.

---

References:

- DeNardis, L., and A.M. Hackl. ‚ÄúInternet Governance by Social Media Platforms.‚Äù
  Telecommunications Policy 39, no. 9 (October 2015): 761‚Äì70.
  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.telpol.2015.04.003.
snippets:
By controlling the flow of digital communication within this garden, social
media platforms are exerting governance.
rawContent:
---
title: "Internet governance by social media platforms"
date: 2023-04-01
tag: [text, essay]
---

By controlling the flow of digital communication within this garden, social
media platforms are exerting governance.

Three thematic areas are focussed on: anonymity and privacy, freedom of speech
and restrictiveness of the platforms' interoperability with other technologies.
Through these themes, platforms attain very strong governmental abilities. They
can counter competitive advantage, remove or block accounts, adhere or decline
the requests of national governments and control how users interact with their
product through different hardware. e.g intentionally making their browser
version of the app terrible to use - thereby navigating around the privacy
constraints of some browsers. Instagram does not let you upload photos via the
computer and google maps performs terribly on mobile browser.

> p. 1 Addresses governance by social media rather than governance of social
> media. Specifically, the article examines the extent to which these platforms
> promote or constrain rights in three thematic areas: anonymity and privacy;
> freedom of speech; and restrictiveness of the platform's interoperability with
> other services and technologies.

> p. 1 The technical infrastructure of the internet is of significant public
> interest implications. The design and administration of this infrastructure is
> commonly referred to as "internet governance"

> p. 2 Looking at the conflicting themes of simultaneous governmental regulation
> and usage of social media, that platforms serve as a type of "privatised
> governance" for the public (potentially leading to dissent).

> p. 2 Governments embed political values in the design and operation of
> internet infrastructures and technologies by way of co-opting the various
> internet governance organisations. This is increasingly done for purposes
> irrelevant to the primary function of internet governance - to keep the
> internet functioning as a sound and unopinionated technical system.

> p. 3 Private companies are taking an increasingly central role in regulating
> civil liberties through the "ongoing privatisation of internet
> governance". This ties in with [The helping hand: In Search of a Swedish
> Institutional Regime for Infrastructural Systems](s2ly), whereby Kaijser shows
> how it has been seen that private intermediaries are given the responsibility
> of managing sections of infrastructure and that this can lead to issues down
> the line.

> p. 4 Interesting cases for why a real name identification policy online can be
> dangerous or impinge on the user's basic rights.

> p. 5 The "privatisation of privacy governance": whether anonymity is
> permissible, what information is collected about users, and how this
> information is shared with third parties.

> p. 6 The Communication Decency Act provides immunity for social media
> platforms against content posted by their users.

> p. 7 The government is constantly requesting social media platforms to remove
> or block content and accounts. Despite this, social media platforms comply
> with a small percentage of requests from the government, showing the power
> these companies do in fact have with regards to controlling content. Social
> media companies release these figures in their Transparency Reports

> p. 8 Platforms often behave like gatekeepers and constrain their users - eg
> maintaining competitive advantage by blocking rival products.
>
> We saw this recently with Musk blocking links to Mastodon.
>
> The disclosure of NSA's mass surveillance incited a greater interest for
> privacy, encryption and routing internet traffic around US servers.
>
> Social media platforms have eroded the interoperability of the internet by
> establishing such great market share, but developing propriatorey API's that
> relate only to their service.

---

References:

- DeNardis, L., and A.M. Hackl. ‚ÄúInternet Governance by Social Media Platforms.‚Äù
  Telecommunications Policy 39, no. 9 (October 2015): 761‚Äì70.
  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.telpol.2015.04.003.

metadata.title: Internet governance by social media platforms

title: Internet search results could be increasing your carbon emissions
link: [Internet search results could be increasing your carbon emissions](r/b8oh)
lead:
> Search engines are more a "wish list" than an authoritative exposure to good
> sources.
body:
> Search engines are more a "wish list" than an authoritative exposure to good
> sources. 

> It's the default options that algorithms work with that define what results
> are returned to us. How are these defaults made? Is it a "natural"
> optimisation through the browsing habits of society at large? Or is it fuelled
> by sales and advertisement?

> Search engine's lead to higher [carbon emissions](../g/ceqj.md) because
> search engines direct user mostly towards the businesses who pay the most to
> Google through advertising, and who are simply the bigger players in the
> economy. These businesses are typically more taxing on the environment as they
> are favouring profit over sustainability. These are companies like major
> fashion brands, airlines over train lines and cheaper Chinese imports over
> local product. 

---
References:

- Haider, Jutta, and Malte R√∂dl. ‚ÄúInternet Search Results Could Be Increasing
  Your Carbon Emissions.‚Äù The Conversation, December 7, 2022.
  http://theconversation.com/internet-search-results-could-be-increasing-your-carbon-emissions-194334.

> sources.

title: LYT - LYT Kit Lessons
lead:
## Home note 
- is the central note of the entire vault. Everything stems from it.
body:
## Home note 
- is the central note of the entire vault. Everything stems from it. 

## Mocs
- Like a worktable, with all relevant index cards.
- An active thinking tool

MOCs are made when you have a large enough amount of notes, whereby you start to
worry about the [Mental Squeeze Point](../4yee)

### Three Phases of Mocs
1. Gather
	1. Gather all relevant notes to that MOC and link to them. 
2. Collide
	1. The most important / fruitful stage.
	2. Dive into each note and flesh it out into an [Evergreen Note](../g/nw1n).
3. Navigate

## Other Fluid Frameworks
- home notes and mocs are "fluid frameworks"
- order *and* chaos. 
- excellent note retrieval *and* the serendipity of discovery


Higher order notes are are notes that have mostly links to other notes. 

## The Process of Note Making

[linking your thinking article](https://notes.linkingyourthinking.com/Cards/On+the+process+of+note-making)
While making a note or revisiting it, you can split the note into different
notes - representing different ideas. Link each of these notes accordingly. From
this, note taking and ideation builds. You don't need to say too much in one
note, and Zettelkasten in fact thrives off this. 

### Mental Squeeze Point

A [Mental Squeeze Point](../4yee) is when your unsorted knowledge becomes so messy it overwhelms and discourages you.
snippets:
## Home note 
- is the central note of the entire vault. Everything stems from it.

date: 2022-07-09 21:57
tags: [video, presentation]

# LYT - LYT Kit Lessons

## Home note 
- is the central note of the entire vault. Everything stems from it. 

## Mocs
- Like a worktable, with all relevant index cards.
- An active thinking tool

MOCs are made when you have a large enough amount of notes, whereby you start to
worry about the [Mental Squeeze Point](../4yee)

### Three Phases of Mocs
1. Gather
	1. Gather all relevant notes to that MOC and link to them. 
2. Collide
	1. The most important / fruitful stage.
	2. Dive into each note and flesh it out into an [Evergreen Note](../g/nw1n).
3. Navigate

## Other Fluid Frameworks
- home notes and mocs are "fluid frameworks"
- order *and* chaos. 
- excellent note retrieval *and* the serendipity of discovery


Higher order notes are are notes that have mostly links to other notes. 

## The Process of Note Making

[linking your thinking article](https://notes.linkingyourthinking.com/Cards/On+the+process+of+note-making)
While making a note or revisiting it, you can split the note into different
notes - representing different ideas. Link each of these notes accordingly. From
this, note taking and ideation builds. You don't need to say too much in one
note, and Zettelkasten in fact thrives off this. 

### Mental Squeeze Point

A [Mental Squeeze Point](../4yee) is when your unsorted knowledge becomes so messy it overwhelms and discourages you.

title: Linux Transition
lead: ## Linux
body:
## Linux

- find good file structure for system config and work / personal files
- set all the correct env variables for shell / system / nvim / bins / $PATHS / XDG_CONFIG / etc before config integration and package download
- make a new tjc conf(?) and be systematic
- place things as close to $HOME as possible to get there easily in terminal
- automated tasks with cron (cronitor to monitor) and systemd

## Security Plan

- [CryptoParty Berlin](https://www.cryptoparty.in/index)
- Keepass
- Nextcloud
- Backup system / software

## Before Selling Mac

- confirm I can extract / view contents of .dmg files (or unextract them all to linuxs own vault system)

###### SEE ALSO
---

# Linux Transition

## Linux

- find good file structure for system config and work / personal files
- set all the correct env variables for shell / system / nvim / bins / $PATHS / XDG_CONFIG / etc before config integration and package download
- make a new tjc conf(?) and be systematic
- place things as close to $HOME as possible to get there easily in terminal
- automated tasks with cron (cronitor to monitor) and systemd

## Security Plan

- [CryptoParty Berlin](https://www.cryptoparty.in/index)
- Keepass
- Nextcloud
- Backup system / software

## Before Selling Mac

- confirm I can extract / view contents of .dmg files (or unextract them all to linuxs own vault system)

###### SEE ALSO

title: LoRaWan
lead:
> Together, [LoRa](0cbi) and LoRaWAN define a Low Power, Wide Area (LPWA) networking
> protocol designed to wirelessly connect battery operated devices to the
> internet in regional, national or global networks, and targets key Internet of
> things (IoT) requirements such as bi-directional communication, end-to-end
> security, mobility and localization services. The low power, low bit rate, and
> IoT use distinguish this type of network from a wireless WAN that is designed
> to connect users or businesses, and carry more data, using more power. The
> LoRaWAN data rate ranges from 0.3 kbit/s to 50 kbit/s per channel.
>
> [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LoRa)

title: Loab, the woman haunting the internet
lead: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-11-26/loab-age-of-artificial-intelligence-future/101678206
body:
https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-11-26/loab-age-of-artificial-intelligence-future/101678206

Loab is the name given to an AI generated image of a woman who consistently
returns to haunt the artist in the article when generating new images.

The artist couldn't escape Loab. Even when providing prompts for unrelated content, Loab would still appear. 

[Adam Curtis](g/64xb)

https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-11-26/loab-age-of-artificial-intelligence-future/101678206

body:
Luke Smith seems like one of those increcibly switched on and high functioning
autistic people who are absolute tech wizards and have an amazing ability to
injest information and recall it really well. 

At the time of writing (March, 2023) I haven't dug that deep into him. But his
[podcasts](https://notrelated.xyz/) are incredibly in depth and the information in them is impressive. I do
get a feeling though that he's a borderline anarchist and while is able to
understand a lot, his attitudes can be a little narrow and unforgiving.

- [Criticisms of Industrialisation](../403a)

# Luke Smith

Luke Smith seems like one of those increcibly switched on and high functioning
autistic people who are absolute tech wizards and have an amazing ability to
injest information and recall it really well. 

At the time of writing (March, 2023) I haven't dug that deep into him. But his
[podcasts](https://notrelated.xyz/) are incredibly in depth and the information in them is impressive. I do
get a feeling though that he's a borderline anarchist and while is able to
understand a lot, his attitudes can be a little narrow and unforgiving.

> Mindfulness meditation cultivates a state of awareness that is less dominated
> by thinking, less stimulated by imagination and memory, less active, and more
> open, receptive and in touch with the aspects of one‚Äôs experience that are
> here and now. Mindfulness practice slows down the forward projection of the

##### loc: 1865 (15-10-2019)

> well be another form of resistance to simply being in the present moment. It
> is almost as if we have an on/off switch in our brain and nervous system: when
> we are busy worrying, judging and planning, the switch is in the on position;
> when there is nothing to plan, judge or worry about, the switch goes to off
> and we fall asleep.  ^ref-32935
Dad

##### loc: 1913 (15-10-2019)
> Remember, with mindfulness, you are not trying to change the contents of your
> awareness‚Äîyour thoughts, feelings and sensations. Rather you are simply and
> profoundly changing your attitude to the contents of your awareness.
> ^ref-39041


##### loc: 1933 (15-10-2019)
> Paul was taught the Three Goodwills by Lama Thubten Yeshe. They are: 1. Bring
> goodwill to your meditation teachers. 2. Bring goodwill to the meditation
> practice‚Äîdo not try to change, improve or adjust it; keep it simple and
> ‚Äòsurrender‚Äô to its simplicity. 3. Bring goodwill to yourself‚Äîdo not judge
> yourself or create high expectations and goals. Be patient and kind and gently
> persevere. When the Three Goodwills are practised with your meditation,
> meditation becomes just like a dear friend: ‚Ä¢ you love spending time with it;
> ‚Ä¢ you give it your full, loving attention; ‚Ä¢ you cherish every meeting; and ‚Ä¢
> you treat it with respect and reverence. In this way, meditation ceases to be
> a chore or a discipline and becomes, instead, a blessed and special time.
> ^ref-23503


##### loc: 2140 (17-10-2019)
> Monkey mind is excessive rumination on hopes, wishes, dreams, concerns and
> worries which habitually recycle through the mind.  ^ref-62691


##### loc: 2405 (24-10-2019)
> The mind withdraws attention from the body and the senses, so excessive
> thinking is non-sense, i.e. nonsense! Mindfulness helps us to release the
> domination of the thinking mind so we can ‚Äòcome to our senses‚Äô.  ^ref-42460


##### loc: 2450 (25-10-2019)
> The way to deal with thoughts when practising Mindfulness of Breath is simply
> to notice the thoughts without making them a problem and without allowing them
> to be important. Upon noticing a thought, we do not fight it yet we do not
> continue to feed it or follow it. We simply open our awareness to include the
> feeling of our breathing‚Äîin other words, we turn our attention back to the
> breathing and allow the thought to run itself out, to move on through.
> ^ref-53085


##### loc: 2479 (27-10-2019)
> The fact that thoughts continue to pop into your mind during meditation is not
> a problem. Each time you notice you have been following thoughts, return to
> the breathing and silently congratulate yourself for changing the old habit of
> attention by coming back to the present moment. If you notice yourself
> following a thought ten times in the space of a minute, then that is ten times
> you can congratulate yourself‚Äînot judge and criticise yourself. Gently
> persevere.  ^ref-19143


##### loc: 2568 (29-10-2019)

##### loc: 2616 (29-10-2019)

> When you realise your mind has wandered away, simply return your attention to

> were distracted or to criticise yourself; simply open your awareness, let the
> thought be and come back to your body sensations. If thoughts about your
> meditation practice intrude, including concerns about whether or not you are
> ‚Äòdoing it correctly‚Äô, or wanting to get somewhere, just notice the
> thoughts‚Äînot feeding them and not fighting them‚Äîand see them as words or

title: Monetary Policy
lead:
Monetary policy is the actions of a central bank that influence the supply of
money to a country and the overall economy. The goal is to keep inflation at a
target rate, which differs from country to country (I think, makes sense).
body:
Monetary policy is the actions of a central bank that influence the supply of
money to a country and the overall economy. The goal is to keep inflation at a
target rate, which differs from country to country (I think, makes sense). 

Releasing money too quickly into the economy creates excessive inflation. 
Releasing it too slowly hampers economic growth.

# Monetary Policy

Monetary policy is the actions of a central bank that influence the supply of
money to a country and the overall economy. The goal is to keep inflation at a
target rate, which differs from country to country (I think, makes sense). 

Releasing money too quickly into the economy creates excessive inflation. 
Releasing it too slowly hampers economic growth.

title: New Dark Age - Is Technology Making the World Harder to Understand?
link: [New Dark Age - Is Technology Making the World Harder to Understand?](r/96rm)
lead:
- 07:00 - Data is getting increasingly difficult to analyze and interpret usefully. Scientific companies are starting to go back to employing groups of scientists to work on hunches.
- 09:00 - Climate change is making it increasingly difficult to predict the future and the technology industry contributes to climate change about the same amount as the airline industry. 
- 10:00 - Indoor Co2 passes 1000 parts per million. Human cognitive ability drops by 20% at this point. 
- 12:45 - Chaotic Storage. Amazon uses this to make distances to collect items smaller. But to get the staff there, they guide them via a wrist mounted display. Effectively surveiling and deskiling the workforce. 
- 16:00 - The above is the same as pokemonGo. 
- 17:00 - Youtube algorhitms guide people into a dark place to corrupt you. 
- 20:30 - The intention isn't to lead people to do bad things, the intention is confusion itself (reference Hypernormalisation and Putins Aid)
- 23:00 - Concrete relationship between the opacity of technological systems and the abuse of them by the ellite.

lead: # Open Source Software Development: Communities‚Äô Impact on Public Good
body:
# Open Source Software Development: Communities‚Äô Impact on Public Good

###### p. 70

Stated that open source projects with contributors who share high
interconnectedness are more likely to face high uncertainty in producing a
collective outcome. That seems weird. 

----
###### p. 71

The availability of free knowledge is assisted by community mobilisation (action
stimulated and sustained by a community of people). Wikipedia is an example. 

---
###### p. 74

Public goods rely on community involvement.

title: Philosophy of technology: The technological condition: An anthology
link: [Philosophy of technology: The technological condition: An anthology](r/hl9g)
lead: # Philosophy of technology: The technological condition: An anthology
body:
# Philosophy of technology: The technological condition: An anthology

## Ch. 45 - Three Ways of Being-With Technology

> p. 524
> Heidegger defines a "being-with" relationship with technology, that develops through technical
> engagements within a context of social exchange. "Such a world is not composed solely of tools and
> artefacts, but of tools used with others and artefacts belonging to others"

---

> "For many people, the ideas that guide their lives may not be held with conscious awareness or
> full participation. They often take the form of myth. Philosophical argument and discussion then
> introduces into such a world of ideas a kind of break or rupture with the immediately given. This
> break or rupture need not require the rejection or abandoning of that given, but it will entail
> the bringing of that given into fuller consciousness or awareness - from which it must be accepted
> (or rejected) in a new way or on new grounds."
snippets: # Philosophy of technology: The technological condition: An anthology

title: Pomodoro Technique
lead: Pomodoro Technique is a productivity technique that uses a timer to break work time into 25 minute chunks.
body:
Pomodoro Technique is a productivity technique that uses a timer to break work time into 25 minute chunks.

The original technique has six steps:

1.  Decide on the task to be done.
2.  Set the pomodoro timer (typically for 25 minutes).
3.  Work on the task.
4.  End work when the timer rings and take a short break (typically 5‚Äì10 minutes).
5.  If you have finished fewer than three pomodoros, go back to Step 2 and repeat until you go through all three pomodoros.
6.  After three pomodoros are done, take the fourth pomodoro and then take a long break (typically 20 to 30 minutes). Once the long break is finished, return to step 2.
snippets: Pomodoro Technique is a productivity technique that uses a timer to break work time into 25 minute chunks.
rawContent:

date: 2022-07-12 10:24
tags: [glossary]
---

# Pomodoro Technique

Pomodoro Technique is a productivity technique that uses a timer to break work time into 25 minute chunks.

The original technique has six steps:

1.  Decide on the task to be done.
2.  Set the pomodoro timer (typically for 25 minutes).
3.  Work on the task.
4.  End work when the timer rings and take a short break (typically 5‚Äì10 minutes).
5.  If you have finished fewer than three pomodoros, go back to Step 2 and repeat until you go through all three pomodoros.
6.  After three pomodoros are done, take the fourth pomodoro and then take a long break (typically 20 to 30 minutes). Once the long break is finished, return to step 2.

title: Snowden, Edward - Permanent Record
lead: > "the substance of communication"  - p. 179
body:
> "the substance of communication"  - p. 179  

The essence of mass surveillance is meta data

> Law lags behind technology by at least a generation - p. 180


> data was later used to identify and ship individuals to death camps. - p. 183-184

The use of technology, is not always in its final form. 

> In an authoritarian state, rights derive from the state and are granted to the
> people. In a free state, rights derive from the people and are granted to the
> state. - p . 206

The difference is between people who are given rights to do something and a
public who "agree to be governed in a covenant of consent that must be
periodically renewed and is constitutionally revocable" - p. 207.

> Ultimately, saying that you don't care about privacy because you have nothing
> to hide is no different from saying you don't care about freedom of speech
> because you have nothing to say. Or that you don't care about freedom of the
> press because you don't like to read. - p. 208

> Saying that you don't need or want privacy because you have nothing to hide is
> to assume that no one should have, or could have, to hide anything --
> including their immigration status, unemployment history, financial history
> and health records. - p. 208

People in general do not fully understand the implications of totally
relinquishing their privacy. Stating that privacy is not needed or wanted is a
selfish statement and does not take into consideration the way that governments,
agencies and companies may manipulate society and people. This is particularly
the case for cultural or religious minorities. 

90% of internet traffic goes through servers owned or operated either directly
or indirectly by the US (stated early in the book). The NSA has a weapon named
TURBULANCE, which watches traffic and flags whether the NSA would find it
suspicious or not. If it is deemed suspicious, (e.g. containing keywords such as
"anonymous internet proxy" or "protest") the HTTPS request gets diverted to an
NSA server which algorithmically defines malware to inject into the web traffic
that arrives back at your computer along with the original web page that you
requested. At that point the NSA has fullcontrol and visibility into your
computer. - p. 225 

> It falls to independent [open-source](../g/8nqd) hardware and software
> developers to close that gap by providing the vital civil liberties
> protections that the law may be unable, or unwilling, to guarantee - p. 239

Here Snowden is talking about how the law lags behind technology so much, that
governments and agencies can use that time to develop technologies that exploit
that lag. An example was given about the move from HTTP to HTTPS. This
technological innovation made it significantly harder for technological
surveillance to occur.
snippets: > "the substance of communication"  - p. 179
rawContent:
