date: 2023-08-01
people: [E.Snowden]
tags: [text, book]
---

# Snowden, Edward - Permanent Record

> "the substance of communication"  - p. 179  

The essence of mass surveillance is meta data

> Law lags behind technology by at least a generation - p. 180


> data was later used to identify and ship individuals to death camps. - p. 183-184

The use of technology, is not always in its final form. 

> In an authoritarian state, rights derive from the state and are granted to the
> people. In a free state, rights derive from the people and are granted to the
> state. - p . 206

The difference is between people who are given rights to do something and a
public who "agree to be governed in a covenant of consent that must be
periodically renewed and is constitutionally revocable" - p. 207.

> Ultimately, saying that you don't care about privacy because you have nothing
> to hide is no different from saying you don't care about freedom of speech
> because you have nothing to say. Or that you don't care about freedom of the
> press because you don't like to read. - p. 208

> Saying that you don't need or want privacy because you have nothing to hide is
> to assume that no one should have, or could have, to hide anything --
> including their immigration status, unemployment history, financial history
> and health records. - p. 208

People in general do not fully understand the implications of totally
relinquishing their privacy. Stating that privacy is not needed or wanted is a
selfish statement and does not take into consideration the way that governments,
agencies and companies may manipulate society and people. This is particularly
the case for cultural or religious minorities. 

90% of internet traffic goes through servers owned or operated either directly
or indirectly by the US (stated early in the book). The NSA has a weapon named
TURBULANCE, which watches traffic and flags whether the NSA would find it
suspicious or not. If it is deemed suspicious, (e.g. containing keywords such as
"anonymous internet proxy" or "protest") the HTTPS request gets diverted to an
NSA server which algorithmically defines malware to inject into the web traffic
that arrives back at your computer along with the original web page that you
requested. At that point the NSA has fullcontrol and visibility into your
computer. - p. 225 

> It falls to independent [open-source](../g/8nqd) hardware and software
> developers to close that gap by providing the vital civil liberties
> protections that the law may be unable, or unwilling, to guarantee - p. 239

Here Snowden is talking about how the law lags behind technology so much, that
governments and agencies can use that time to develop technologies that exploit
that lag. An example was given about the move from HTTP to HTTPS. This
technological innovation made it significantly harder for technological
surveillance to occur.

title: Some Thoughts on the Question "How Do New Things Happen?"
link: [Some Thoughts on the Question "How Do New Things Happen?"](r/u1om)
lead: # Some Thoughts on the Question "How Do New Things Happen?"
body:
# Some Thoughts on the Question "How Do New Things Happen?"

A speech given at SHOT. Summarises to a call-to-action that scholars and
reporters should draw more focus to "subaltern" subcultures who use
technologies in "insurgent" ways. It is these subcultures who have the power to
shift the patterns that she has been observing in the media industry since she
left grad school and begun studying radio as a communication medium. 

She goes through some progressions of the media industry and it's technologies
and outlines how due to world events such as 9/11 and technological innovations
(things getting faster and more accessible) a media culture has developed with
it's substance in narcissism and fear mongering. 

But this can be navigated by searching on the fringes and in the subcultures to
get the real value from the media industry and its reporting. 

> p. 295 Media frameworks consolidate a type of ideology of technology, which
> follows the form of a prevailing common sense. 

> p. 296 It is noted that subcultures who use technologies in "insurgent" ways
> can and have had assisted in technologies altering the course of history.
> These are hackers and shows the power and value of
> the [the hacker ethic](../yf8s). 

> p. 297 Pondered "what it meant to have a communications and entertainment
> technology that denies sight to its audience."

> p. 298 Radio enabled not only a recognition between each listener of a shared
> act of listening, but also a shared act of cognition. A cognition of
> imagination. This helped tie a society together that was broken from the
> depression of the 1930's. 

> p. 300 Douglas began to consider that all technologies are scopic and allow
> us to look inwards and outwards. 

> p. 300 Through the profit based progress of media technologies, we have seen
> an "implosion of culture"

> p. 301 The 70's showed us that with geo-satelite transmission and a
> transition from film to video, news media begun to report live. This
> "liveness" meant that people could be delivered news as it was happening from
> anywhere in the globe. However, as it was deemed that the most newsworthy
> items (those that maintained the most viewers) was contextualised first and
> foremost by conflict and disasters. The public therefore saw the world as a
> place full of wars, famine, floods, genocides and dictators. 
> 

---

- Susan J. Douglas. ‚ÄúSome Thoughts on the Question ‚ÄòHow Do New Things Happen?‚Äô‚Äù
  Technology and Culture 51, no. 2 (2010): 293‚Äì304.
  https://doi.org/10.1353/tech.0.0478.

title: 'Some Thoughts on the Question "How Do New Things Happen?"'
date: 2023-04-01

# Some Thoughts on the Question "How Do New Things Happen?"

A speech given at SHOT. Summarises to a call-to-action that scholars and
reporters should draw more focus to "subaltern" subcultures who use
technologies in "insurgent" ways. It is these subcultures who have the power to
shift the patterns that she has been observing in the media industry since she
left grad school and begun studying radio as a communication medium. 

She goes through some progressions of the media industry and it's technologies
and outlines how due to world events such as 9/11 and technological innovations
(things getting faster and more accessible) a media culture has developed with
it's substance in narcissism and fear mongering. 

But this can be navigated by searching on the fringes and in the subcultures to
get the real value from the media industry and its reporting. 

> p. 295 Media frameworks consolidate a type of ideology of technology, which
> follows the form of a prevailing common sense. 

> p. 296 It is noted that subcultures who use technologies in "insurgent" ways
> can and have had assisted in technologies altering the course of history.
> These are hackers and shows the power and value of
> the [the hacker ethic](../yf8s). 

> p. 297 Pondered "what it meant to have a communications and entertainment
> technology that denies sight to its audience."

> p. 298 Radio enabled not only a recognition between each listener of a shared
> act of listening, but also a shared act of cognition. A cognition of
> imagination. This helped tie a society together that was broken from the
> depression of the 1930's. 

> p. 300 Douglas began to consider that all technologies are scopic and allow
> us to look inwards and outwards. 

> p. 300 Through the profit based progress of media technologies, we have seen
> an "implosion of culture"

> p. 301 The 70's showed us that with geo-satelite transmission and a
> transition from film to video, news media begun to report live. This
> "liveness" meant that people could be delivered news as it was happening from
> anywhere in the globe. However, as it was deemed that the most newsworthy
> items (those that maintained the most viewers) was contextualised first and
> foremost by conflict and disasters. The public therefore saw the world as a
> place full of wars, famine, floods, genocides and dictators. 
> 

---
References:

- Susan J. Douglas. ‚ÄúSome Thoughts on the Question ‚ÄòHow Do New Things Happen?‚Äô‚Äù
  Technology and Culture 51, no. 2 (2010): 293‚Äì304.
  https://doi.org/10.1353/tech.0.0478.

title: Strength in Stillness
lead: Note: Trancendental meditation is a pyramid scheme.
body:
Note: Trancendental meditation is a pyramid scheme.

##### loc: 98 (30-09-2019)

> People at the top of their game love to be challenged. But whether you love or
> hate your job, you can still pay the physical and emotional tolls of stress.
> ^ref-5731

---

##### loc: 157 (01-10-2019)

> EEG readouts measured while test subjects practise Focused Attention show that
> these techniques enliven gamma brain waves in the left prefrontal cortex, the
> brain‚Äôs decision maker. This means that the electrical activity in the brain
> reaches a frequency per second of about 20 to 50 hertz (Hz), or cycles per
> second. You see a similar result when a student concentrates on a mathematical
> problem ‚Äì which makes sense, because gamma waves are found when one is engaged
> in a challenging task. In contrast to attempting to clear the mind of
> thoughts, the second category of meditation, Open Monitoring, also known as
> mindfulness, is about learning to observe thoughts dispassionately, without
> judgement, as they come and go. This is because thoughts themselves are not
> seen as the potential disrupter of calm, but rather it is the content or
> meaning of thoughts that can disrupt.  ^ref-32624

---

##### loc: 164 (01-10-2019)

> Back to the ocean analogy.  ^ref-18525

---

##### loc: 178 (01-10-2019)

> Transcendental Meditation is in this category. Let‚Äôs return to the ocean
> analogy yet again: there are active, often turbulent waves on the surface, but
> there is calm at its depth. In the same way, we hypothesize that while the
> mind is active on the surface, deep within is a level that is calm yet alert;
> silent yet wide awake. The ancient meditation texts refer to it as the ‚Äòsource
> of thought‚Äô or ‚Äòpure consciousness‚Äô ‚Äì a field of limitless creativity,
> intelligence and energy within. Scientists give it a more clinical
> description: a state of ‚Äòrestful alertness.‚Äô  ^ref-53905

---

##### loc: 190 (01-10-2019)

> EEG readouts and brain imaging reveal that Transcendental Meditation
> strengthens the neural connections between the different areas of the brain,
> including within the prefrontal cortex, to promote better learning and
> decision making.  ^ref-51694

---

##### loc: 459 (02-10-2019)

> getting out of bed and then . . . resting! I had trouble with that  ^ref-53929

---

##### loc: 447 (02-10-2019)

> But each time you meditate, even if your mind is filled with a million
> thoughts, you do settle down toward levels of the mind that are deeper,
> quieter, more satisfying. And when you do that, the equanimity you experience
> during meditation naturally comes out to be lived more and more in every
> moment of your life. And that is a very good description of the zone.
> ^ref-55985


---
References:

- https://stillnessbook.com/

title: Structure-mapping: A theoretical framework for analogy
lead: # Structure-mapping: A theoretical framework for analogy
body:
# Structure-mapping: A theoretical framework for analogy

> p. 2 Domains and situations of an analogy are psychologically viewed as
> systems of objects (a rabbit), object-attributes (a rabbits ear) and relations
> between objects (herd of rabbits).

> p. 3 Knowledge is represented in the paper as propositional networks of nodes.
> They're mapping knowledge in a node / network graph in order to describe and
> represent relationships. This is in essence how the [zettelkasten](../i/512g) is
> working and naturally has parallels to the topic of decentralisation. 

---
Research:

- Gentner, Dedre. ‚ÄúStructure-Mapping: A Theoretical Framework for Analogy.‚Äù
  Cognitive Science 7, no. 2 (April 1, 1983): 155‚Äì70.
  https://doi.org/10.1016/S0364-0213(83)80009-3.

# Swinburne University of Technology - multi-strain synbiotic trial

This was the trial that mum took part in. It looked at a new mutli-strain
synbiotic and its effect in elderly for (from memory) bone density and muscle
mass growth.

Mum said it made a huge difference. She regained a lot of balance, muscle and
also slept much better.

The strain was: u Bifidobacterium animalis B94 u Lactobacillus helveticus R0052
u Bifidobacterium longum R0175

title: Techniques for Precise Academic Writing
lead: ## General Notes
body:
## General Notes

Use clean, simple language.
Use as few words as possible.

## CTech Script Ref

[CTech writing script](https://github.com/ctechfilmuniversity/lecture_academic_methodologies/blob/main/docs/02_scripts/am_ss22_09_writing_script.md)

The website [daily writing tips](https://www.dailywritingtips.com/) describes the following helpful [techniques for more precise writing](https://www.dailywritingtips.com/10-techniques-for-more-precise-writing/)
¬ª **Lena says: At all costs try to avoid passive!**

1.  Use Active Voice
    When a sentence includes _be_ or any other copulative verb, such as _is_ or _are_, recast the sentence to omit the verb.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThe meeting was seen by us as a ploy to delay the project.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúWe saw the meeting as a ploy to delay the project.‚Äù

2.  Avoid Vague Nouns
    Phrases formed around general nouns such as _aspect_, _degree_, and _situation_ clutter sentences.

    Don't: ‚ÄúShe is an expert in the area of international relations.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúShe is an expert in international relations.‚Äù

3.  Use Words, Not Their Definitions
    Replace explanatory phrases with a single word that encapsulates that explanation.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThe crops also needed to be marketable so that families would be able to sell any yields that exceeded what they personally required.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThe crops also needed to be marketable so that families would be able to sell any surplus.‚Äù

4.  Avoid Noun Strings
    Reorganize sentences to eliminate series of nouns used as adjectives.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThe lack of a secure transfer may hamper computer security incident response efforts.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThe lack of a secure transfer may hamper responses to computer-security incidents.‚Äù

5.  Convert Nouns to Verbs
    When a sentence includes a noun ending in _-tion_, change the noun to a verb to simplify the sentence.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThey will collaborate in the creation of new guidelines.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThey will collaborate to create new guidelines.‚Äù

    or en example without a _-tion_:

    Don't: ‚ÄúThis paragraph provides a conclusion of the description‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThis paragraph concludes the description‚Äù

6.  Reduce Verb Phrases to Simple Verbs
    Identify the verb buried in a verb phrase and omit the rest of the phrase.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThe results are suggestive of the fact that tampering has occurred.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThe results suggest that tampering has occurred.‚Äù

7.  Replace Complex Words with Simple Ones
    Choose simpler synonyms for multisyllabic words. I am not sure I agree with this - it is up to your personal style.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThe department will disseminate the forms soon.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThe department will pass out the forms soon.‚Äù

8.  Avoid Expletives
    Don‚Äôt start sentences with ‚ÄúThere is,‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt is.‚Äù

    Don't: ‚ÄúThere are many factors in the product‚Äôs failure.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúMany factors contributed to the product‚Äôs failure.‚Äù

9.  Eliminate Prepositional Phrases Replace ‚Äú(noun1) of the (noun2)‚Äù phrasing with ‚Äú(noun2)‚Äôs (noun1)‚Äù phrasing.

    Don't: ‚ÄúThe decision of the committee is final.‚Äù
    Do: ‚ÄúThe committee‚Äôs decision is final.‚Äù

10. Reduce Wordy Phrases to Single Words
    Replace phrases that signal a transition with simple conjunctions, verbs, or other linking words.

## More Dos and Donts

Don't: Due to the fact that the project is behind schedule, today‚Äôs meeting has been postponed.
**Do:** Because the project is behind schedule, today‚Äôs meeting has been postponed.

Don't: ‚ÄúThe meeting was seen as a ploy to delay the project.‚Äù
**Do:** ‚ÄúWe saw the meeting as a ploy to delay the project.‚Äù
But don‚Äôt do this: ‚ÄúWe then sort the vertices by height‚Ä¶‚Äù. Unless you are manually doing the sorting yourself, and not the algorithm.

Don't: "The decision of the committee was..."
**Do:** "The committee's decision was "

Avoid:

- emotional language (we feel very strongly...)
- flowery language
- superlatives (coldest, tallest, softest, etc)
- "it was very impressive"

## Grammar and Tense

### Present Tense

In a paper everything you do is in present tense, also things that come later in the paper.
Don't: "In Section 3 we are going to show‚Ä¶"
Do: ‚ÄúIn Section 3 we are showing‚Ä¶"

### Which vs. That

One of my personal pet peeves is the incorrect use of _which_ vs. _that_.
_That_

- Introduces what is called an essential clause. Essential clauses add information that is vital to the point of the sentence and can not be left out.
- Example: I do not trust products that claim "all natural ingredients" because this phrase can mean almost anything.
  - We would not know the type of products being discussed without the _that_ clause.

_Which_

- Introduces a nonessential clause, which adds supplementary information.
- Example: The product claiming "all natural ingredients," which appeared in the Sunday newspaper, is on sale.
  - The product is already identified. Therefore, which appeared in the Sunday newspaper is a nonessential clause containing additional, but not essential, information.

Essential clauses (that) do not have comma introducing or surrounding them, whereas nonessential clauses (which) are introduced or surrounded by commata!

10. Reduce Wordy Phrases to Single Words

## More Dos and Donts

Don't: Due to the fact that the project is behind schedule, today‚Äôs meeting has been postponed.

title: Technological Determinism
lead:
> Technological determinism seeks to show technical developments, media, or
> technology as a whole, as the key mover in history and social change. It is a
> theory subscribed to by "hyperglobalists" who claim that as a consequence of
> the wide availability of technology, accelerated globalization is inevitable.
> Therefore, technological development and innovation become the principal motor
> of social, economic or political change.
body:
> Technological determinism seeks to show technical developments, media, or
> technology as a whole, as the key mover in history and social change. It is a
> theory subscribed to by "hyperglobalists" who claim that as a consequence of
> the wide availability of technology, accelerated globalization is inevitable.
> Therefore, technological development and innovation become the principal motor
> of social, economic or political change.

In other words, to say that technology determines society would mean that
society does not have a role in determining the advent of technologies.

A competing theory is the [Anchor Network Theory](5c0r)
([ref](https://www.simplypsychology.org/actor-network-theory.html)).

> Therefore, technological development and innovation become the principal motor
> of social, economic or political change.

# Technological Determinism

> Technological determinism seeks to show technical developments, media, or
> technology as a whole, as the key mover in history and social change. It is a
> theory subscribed to by "hyperglobalists" who claim that as a consequence of
> the wide availability of technology, accelerated globalization is inevitable.
> Therefore, technological development and innovation become the principal motor
> of social, economic or political change.

In other words, to say that technology determines society would mean that
society does not have a role in determining the advent of technologies.

A competing theory is the [Anchor Network Theory](5c0r)
([ref](https://www.simplypsychology.org/actor-network-theory.html)).

title: The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious
body:
##### loc: 449 (06-06-2022)

> He stood on a mountain slope with a deep valley below, and in it a dark lake.
> He knew in the dream that something had always prevented him from approaching
> the lake. This time he resolved to go to the water. As he approached the
> shore, everything grew dark and uncanny, and a gust of wind suddenly rushed
> over the face of the water. He was seized by a panic fear, and awoke.
> ^ref-6572

---

##### loc: 480 (06-06-2022)

> Water is the commonest symbol for the unconscious. The lake in the valley is
> the unconscious, which lies, as it were, underneath consciousness, so that it
> is often referred to as the ‚Äúsubconscious,‚Äù  ^ref-16456

---

##### loc: 533 (08-06-2022)

> But one must learn to know oneself in order to know who one is. For what
> comes after the door is, surprisingly enough, a boundless expanse full of
> unprecedented uncertainty, with apparently no inside and no outside, no above
> and no below, no here and no there, no mine and no thine, no good and no bad.
> It is the world of water, where all life floats in suspension; where the
> realm of the sympathetic system, the soul of everything living, begins; where
> I am indivisibly this and that; where I experience the other in myself and
> the other-than-myself experiences me.  ^ref-2711

To learn to know onesself is to be aware. [meditation is a practice of being aware](../817y)

---

##### loc: 1019 (29-06-2022)

> The question is simply this: are there or are there not unconscious,
> universal forms of this kind? If they exist, then there is a region of the
> psyche which one can call the collective unconscious.  ^ref-18007

---

##### loc: 1021 (29-06-2022)

> It is not sufficient to point out the often obviously archetypal nature of
> unconscious products, for these can just as well be derived from acquisitions
> through language and education.  ^ref-55635

---

##### loc: 1093 (29-06-2022)

> When a situation occurs which corresponds to a given archetype, that
> archetype becomes activated and a compulsiveness appears, which, like an
> instinctual drive, gains its way against all reason and will, or else
> produces a conflict of pathological dimensions, that is to say, a neurosis.
> ^ref-28944

---

##### loc: 1097 (29-06-2022)

> Since archetypes are supposed to produce certain psychic forms, we must
> discuss how and where one can get hold of the material demonstrating these
> forms. The main source, then, is dreams, which have the advantage of being
> involuntary, spontaneous products of the unconscious psyche and are therefore
> pure products of nature not falsified by any conscious purpose.  ^ref-23389

---

##### loc: 1099 (29-06-2022)

> By questioning the individual one can ascertain which of the motifs appearing
> in the dream are known to him. From those which are unknown to him we must
> naturally exclude all motifs which might be known to him,  ^ref-6995

---

##### loc: 1106 (29-06-2022)

> Another source for the material we need is to be found in ‚Äúactive
> imagination.‚Äù By this I mean a sequence of fantasies produced by deliberate
> concentration. I have found that the existence of unrealized, unconscious
> fantasies increases the frequency and intensity of dreams, and that when
> these fantasies are made conscious the dreams change their character and
> become weaker and less frequent.  ^ref-1049

title: The Changelog - AI Assisted Programming and Tab Nine
link: [The Changelog - AI Assisted Programming and Tab Nine](r/5tx8)
lead: [Tab nine](https://www.tabnine.com/) - AI assisted code completion. Based on the idea of program synthesis.
body:
[Tab nine](https://www.tabnine.com/) - AI assisted code completion. Based on the idea of program synthesis.

Professor suggests that AI won't replace developers because the main part of
coding is actually "discovering the spec" you want (what does this mean?). It's
still difficult for the AI to know exactly what you want - and it's also
difficult for the user to end up with a fully written program while also knowing
that this is working exactly how desired.

Seems like in the end being a good prgrammer is being able to think creatively
and with broad scope. Applications like this will stop this kind of thinking and
bottleneck the creativity of programmers - by funnelling their output down the
same direction of coding outcomes and patterns.

### Why Do People Like This?

You don't necessarily know what you're going to get - and this can be magical
and surprising. You can take these happy accidents and bring it into your
programming. People are happy for the prediction to be accurate and interesting.

The AI is trained off your own data base - it's personalised. Micorsoft's
/ GitHub's Co-Pilot is based on non-personalised data bases.

### How It's Working

It actually predicts an entire code snipped it the background - or can. But it
only displays line by line, so the user can snap decision yes / no. The AI also
learns from these decisions.

### OpenAI

Tabnine uses OpenAI licensesed AI. Not trained on [GPL (free software
license)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_General_Public_License) "General
Public License".

Free Liceces: MIT - Apache2 - BSD2 Clause and BSD3.

### Hack

You can theoretically get other people's code and train the AI on it, so that
the AI can then be used to write software in the hand of the other
programmers...

### Ethics

Although these programmers are built on free licenses, the end result is
a product that enables people to undertake unethical actions.

goteleport.com - certificate based access to all cloud computing services you
use at the same time. Enabling better workflow. Certificates expire at the end
of the day - enhanced security.

### Use Cases

Could Tabnine be trained on all individulas of a team and sync between users so
that the users in that team can write a style of code that is aggregated from
each users. Creating one uniform unit - like networking computers together?

# The Changelog - AI Assisted Programming and Tab Nine

[Tab nine](https://www.tabnine.com/) - AI assisted code completion. Based on the idea of program synthesis.

Professor suggests that AI won't replace developers because the main part of
coding is actually "discovering the spec" you want (what does this mean?). It's
still difficult for the AI to know exactly what you want - and it's also
difficult for the user to end up with a fully written program while also knowing
that this is working exactly how desired.

Seems like in the end being a good prgrammer is being able to think creatively
and with broad scope. Applications like this will stop this kind of thinking and
bottleneck the creativity of programmers - by funnelling their output down the
same direction of coding outcomes and patterns.

### Why Do People Like This?

You don't necessarily know what you're going to get - and this can be magical
and surprising. You can take these happy accidents and bring it into your
programming. People are happy for the prediction to be accurate and interesting.

The AI is trained off your own data base - it's personalised. Micorsoft's
/ GitHub's Co-Pilot is based on non-personalised data bases.

### How It's Working

It actually predicts an entire code snipped it the background - or can. But it
only displays line by line, so the user can snap decision yes / no. The AI also
learns from these decisions.

### OpenAI

Tabnine uses OpenAI licensesed AI. Not trained on [GPL (free software
license)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_General_Public_License) "General
Public License".

Free Liceces: MIT - Apache2 - BSD2 Clause and BSD3.

### Hack

You can theoretically get other people's code and train the AI on it, so that
the AI can then be used to write software in the hand of the other
programmers...

### Ethics

Although these programmers are built on free licenses, the end result is
a product that enables people to undertake unethical actions.

goteleport.com - certificate based access to all cloud computing services you
use at the same time. Enabling better workflow. Certificates expire at the end
of the day - enhanced security.

### Use Cases

Could Tabnine be trained on all individulas of a team and sync between users so
that the users in that team can write a style of code that is aggregated from
each users. Creating one uniform unit - like networking computers together?

title: The Changelog - Engineering Interview Tips and Tricks
link: [The Changelog - Engineering Interview Tips and Tricks](r/p685)
lead:
Not a good idea to apply to jobs where you know everything (therefore in tech,
technically overqualified)
body:
Not a good idea to apply to jobs where you know everything (therefore in tech,
technically overqualified)

If you do an interview with a CTO / CEO at a large company as a junior engineer
then something is probably wrong.

Interview process for startups can take a few weeks. Big companies can take 4-6
months.

Green Flags:

- Being able to think out loud, systematically and in continuous steps
- Being honest, low ego, good communicator, working well in a team and willing
  to learn from mistakes
- Being empathetic, thoughtful in the moment - even if it takes more time to
  answer a coding question
- Candidates that research about the company before the interview and asks
  questions and shows interest in the interview
- Thanking the interviewee, also after the interview via email / linked in

Red Flags:

- Empathy towards the customer (don't suggest you think they're dumb or
  controllable, etc)
- Showing a quality of needing to be _right_ rather than _understood_
- Not bring strong examples of career moments of failure, difficulties or
  challenges

Junior / Senior

- Generally junior engineer jobs allow more so for leaning on the job. This
  understanding should be shown in the interview.
- At all levels, it is expected (and understood) that things will need to be
  learned **and that you don't know everything**
- At a senior level, it's also about how much people will be able to rely on you
  as a good collaborator, teacher and mentor

# The Changelog - Engineering Interview Tips and Tricks

Not a good idea to apply to jobs where you know everything (therefore in tech,
technically overqualified)

If you do an interview with a CTO / CEO at a large company as a junior engineer
then something is probably wrong.

Interview process for startups can take a few weeks. Big companies can take 4-6
months.

Green Flags:

- Being able to think out loud, systematically and in continuous steps
- Being honest, low ego, good communicator, working well in a team and willing
  to learn from mistakes
- Being empathetic, thoughtful in the moment - even if it takes more time to
  answer a coding question
- Candidates that research about the company before the interview and asks
  questions and shows interest in the interview
- Thanking the interviewee, also after the interview via email / linked in

Red Flags:

- Empathy towards the customer (don't suggest you think they're dumb or
  controllable, etc)
- Showing a quality of needing to be _right_ rather than _understood_
- Not bring strong examples of career moments of failure, difficulties or
  challenges

Junior / Senior

- Generally junior engineer jobs allow more so for leaning on the job. This
  understanding should be shown in the interview.
- At all levels, it is expected (and understood) that things will need to be
  learned **and that you don't know everything**
- At a senior level, it's also about how much people will be able to rely on you
  as a good collaborator, teacher and mentor

title: The Changelog and Friends 23 - The state of the 2023 tech market
link: [The Changelog and Friends 23 - The state of the 2023 tech market](r/jyhl)
body:
## 02:00

The compiler provided a 10x improvement to programming productivity, yet it only 
increased the demand for programmers. The internet spawned the job of a web 
developer, who used to be few and expensive. Now non-developers can build websites, 
but the demand for web developers is higher than ever. 

The trend seems to be that improvements in developer productivity and technology 
only increase the demand for developers. AI could well in theory continue in 
this trend by making develoeprs more productive and therefore able to tackle more 
tasks. It will also enable many smaller businesses to hire people for small jobs, 
apps, services, that would otherwise be too expensive for them or too difficult 
for novice developers. 

## 08:50

Jerod is amazed by how many new ideas he's seeing due to the advent of AI.
A "net positive"

Gergerly says that with the increase of AI code, we will end up with code bases 
of much more complex and buggy code than before. This is because people may not 
have the expertise, time or desire to identify problems before integrating AI 
generated code. He therefore thinks that there will be an increased demand for 
developers who know the deeper and finer details of the tech stack, as they will 
be the ones who are truly valuable at a higher level. 

In other words, there will be more and more developers who have an increasingly 
high level understanding of the tools and domains they work in.

This is in line with my general belief that [a deep understanding is a valuable asset](../9fn5).

Gergerly thinks in the future that the bootcamp entry path will no longer work. 
A higher knowledge foundation will be a requirement of a first job.

## 13:00ish

Stackoverflow sold for 1.8Billion...

## 18:30

> The messy part in tech and the hardest to figure out is humans. 
> - Gergerly

## 29:00

Talking about OpenAI firing  [Sam Altman](../g/qckt) OpenAI is incredibly
important to Microsoft.

# The Changelog and Friends 23 - The state of the 2023 tech market

## 02:00

The compiler provided a 10x improvement to programming productivity, yet it only 
increased the demand for programmers. The internet spawned the job of a web 
developer, who used to be few and expensive. Now non-developers can build websites, 
but the demand for web developers is higher than ever. 

The trend seems to be that improvements in developer productivity and technology 
only increase the demand for developers. AI could well in theory continue in 
this trend by making develoeprs more productive and therefore able to tackle more 
tasks. It will also enable many smaller businesses to hire people for small jobs, 
apps, services, that would otherwise be too expensive for them or too difficult 
for novice developers. 

## 08:50

Jerod is amazed by how many new ideas he's seeing due to the advent of AI.
A "net positive"

Gergerly says that with the increase of AI code, we will end up with code bases 
of much more complex and buggy code than before. This is because people may not 
have the expertise, time or desire to identify problems before integrating AI 
generated code. He therefore thinks that there will be an increased demand for 
developers who know the deeper and finer details of the tech stack, as they will 
be the ones who are truly valuable at a higher level. 

In other words, there will be more and more developers who have an increasingly 
high level understanding of the tools and domains they work in.

This is in line with my general belief that [a deep understanding is a valuable asset](../9fn5).

Gergerly thinks in the future that the bootcamp entry path will no longer work. 
A higher knowledge foundation will be a requirement of a first job.

## 13:00ish

Stackoverflow sold for 1.8Billion...

## 18:30

> The messy part in tech and the hardest to figure out is humans. 
> - Gergerly

## 29:00

Talking about OpenAI firing  [Sam Altman](../g/qckt) OpenAI is incredibly
important to Microsoft.

body:
The GAN model was invented in Th√ºbingen by [Gatys, Ecker and Bethge](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Gatys_Image_Style_Transfer_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf)
It involves a model in essence training itself (unsupervised learning) by generating data and testing it against itself (a converstation between the Generator and Discriminator). 

In their paper, they showed it's functionality with images whereby the process called style transfer was invnted and coined. 

However it's also used to teach a ML model how to overcome a problem, as seen here.

# The GAN ML Model

The GAN model was invented in Th√ºbingen by [Gatys, Ecker and Bethge](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Gatys_Image_Style_Transfer_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf)
It involves a model in essence training itself (unsupervised learning) by generating data and testing it against itself (a converstation between the Generator and Discriminator). 

In their paper, they showed it's functionality with images whereby the process called style transfer was invnted and coined. 

However it's also used to teach a ML model how to overcome a problem, as seen here.

title: The Iceberg Yes
lead:
Iceberg "yes". Saying yes to something, but understanding the hidden things,
below the request, you are also saying yes to.
body:
Iceberg "yes". Saying yes to something, but understanding the hidden things,
below the request, you are also saying yes to.

It's a system for helping define when to say yes to something or not. You

title: The Machine Mind
lead:
When you're getting stuck in a state of negativity, anxiety or frustration, use
The Machine Mind. [The past is a fact, the future is a possibility](gzma). Move
forward.
body:
When you're getting stuck in a state of negativity, anxiety or frustration, use
The Machine Mind. [The past is a fact, the future is a possibility](gzma). Move
forward.

Occurrences in the past do not have an emotional context for a machine. It only
sees the past as a set of data points, and uses them to asses possibilities in
the future. This is the most optimal way of operating - in terms of being
efficient.

The emotional state is not something to avoid, or rid ourselves of. But it is
something that can get the better of us, particularly when it is a negative
experience. But all things past do come to rest eventually. Not getting caught
up in the negative ones allows us to move forward positively. Respect the
negativity, but use it to move forward positively.

# The Machine Mind

When you're getting stuck in a state of negativity, anxiety or frustration, use
The Machine Mind. [The past is a fact, the future is a possibility](gzma). Move
forward.

Occurrences in the past do not have an emotional context for a machine. It only
sees the past as a set of data points, and uses them to asses possibilities in
the future. This is the most optimal way of operating - in terms of being
efficient.

The emotional state is not something to avoid, or rid ourselves of. But it is
something that can get the better of us, particularly when it is a negative
experience. But all things past do come to rest eventually. Not getting caught
up in the negative ones allows us to move forward positively. Respect the
negativity, but use it to move forward positively.

title: The Prophets of Cryptocurrency
lead:
I wanted to frame my understanding of the current crypto crash by looking back
at the past one. I feel like in the 2018 crash, the same feelings of hindsight,
doom and gloom, told-you-so attitudes would have been present. Then the price of
crypto was still for a while until this surge, which completely and utterly
dwarfs the preceding one.
body:
I wanted to frame my understanding of the current crypto crash by looking back
at the past one. I feel like in the 2018 crash, the same feelings of hindsight,
doom and gloom, told-you-so attitudes would have been present. Then the price of
crypto was still for a while until this surge, which completely and utterly
dwarfs the preceding one. 

So I went searching for articles from that time frame to see what the tone of
the moment was. In this article on The New Yorker was this little statement
about Buterin:

> He envisaged a one-blade-fits-all version, a blockchain platform that was
> broader and more adaptable to a wider array of uses and applications. The
> concept behind Bitcoin‚Äîa network of machines all over the world‚Äîseemed to be
> a building block upon which to construct a global computer capable of all
> kinds of activities.

This makes it clearer as to the value of Blockchain technology,
cryptocurrency being the method of transaction within that network. The
problem before with giant networks of computers was security, but the Blockchain
is set to solve this problem. So it could be a monumental shift in the way the
internet, and specifically transactions on the internet move forward. What the
online world needs moving forward is an effective method of
decentralisation.

This is also why I believe Bitcoin will eventually fully fade out, it doesn't
aim to solve any problem except that of payments. There's no network ecosystem
around it. There's no value.

dwarfs the preceding one.

# The Prophets of Cryptocurrency

I wanted to frame my understanding of the current crypto crash by looking back
at the past one. I feel like in the 2018 crash, the same feelings of hindsight,
doom and gloom, told-you-so attitudes would have been present. Then the price of
crypto was still for a while until this surge, which completely and utterly
dwarfs the preceding one. 

So I went searching for articles from that time frame to see what the tone of
the moment was. In this article on The New Yorker was this little statement
about Buterin:

> He envisaged a one-blade-fits-all version, a blockchain platform that was
> broader and more adaptable to a wider array of uses and applications. The
> concept behind Bitcoin‚Äîa network of machines all over the world‚Äîseemed to be
> a building block upon which to construct a global computer capable of all
> kinds of activities.

This makes it clearer as to the value of Blockchain technology,
cryptocurrency being the method of transaction within that network. The
problem before with giant networks of computers was security, but the Blockchain
is set to solve this problem. So it could be a monumental shift in the way the
internet, and specifically transactions on the internet move forward. What the
online world needs moving forward is an effective method of
decentralisation.

This is also why I believe Bitcoin will eventually fully fade out, it doesn't
aim to solve any problem except that of payments. There's no network ecosystem
around it. There's no value.

title: The relationship between feelings of knowing and the number of neighboring concepts linked to the test cue
link: [The relationship between feelings of knowing and the number of neighboring concepts linked to the test cue](r/pdyh)
lead:
# The relationship between feelings of knowing and the number of neighboring
# concepts linked to the test cue
body:
# The relationship between feelings of knowing and the number of neighboring
# concepts linked to the test cue 

Question posed: 

> How do people determine that they know information learned earlier 
> even when they cannot reacll that information at the moment?

*partial-retrieval hypothosis* suggests that the feeling-of-knowing 
is based on related information that comes to mind while searching 
memory for something specific.

‚Ä† Zeigarnic could [remember everything](../g/547m). There was no "feeling-of-knowing".

---
References:

- Schreiber, Thomas A., and Douglas L. Nelson. ‚ÄúThe Relation between Feelings
  of Knowing and the Number of Neighboring Concepts Linked to the Test Cue.‚Äù
  Memory & Cognition 26, no. 5 (September 1, 1998): 869‚Äì83.
  https://doi.org/10.3758/BF03201170.

# concepts linked to the test cue

title: Virtual Machines
lead:
Back in the day, organizations ran applications on physical servers. This was
the best solution at the time. But the problem was the limited resources of the
server itself. The server would run multiple programs, but if one program was
used in a way that required more resources than the others, then the other
programs would underperform due to lack of resources.
body:
Back in the day, organizations ran applications on physical servers. This was
the best solution at the time. But the problem was the limited resources of the
server itself. The server would run multiple programs, but if one program was
used in a way that required more resources than the others, then the other
programs would underperform due to lack of resources. 

The following solution was to make virtual machines. These run on a single
servers CPU. Each VM runs it's own operating system on top of the servers
hardware and has the same amount of resources delegated to it. This solution
also offers more security, as the VM is self contained and therefore data cannot
be as easily accessed from one VM to the other. 

The era following this, which we are currently in uses container deployment.

server itself. The server would run multiple programs, but if one program was

programs would underperform due to lack of resources.

# Virtual Machines

Back in the day, organizations ran applications on physical servers. This was
the best solution at the time. But the problem was the limited resources of the
server itself. The server would run multiple programs, but if one program was
used in a way that required more resources than the others, then the other
programs would underperform due to lack of resources. 

The following solution was to make virtual machines. These run on a single
servers CPU. Each VM runs it's own operating system on top of the servers
hardware and has the same amount of resources delegated to it. This solution
also offers more security, as the VM is self contained and therefore data cannot
be as easily accessed from one VM to the other. 

The era following this, which we are currently in uses container deployment.

title: What and where is the Internet? (Re)defining Internet histories
link: [What and where is the Internet? (Re)defining Internet histories](r/c70c)
lead:
An essay about "the strengths and limitations of three broad ways of framing
Internet histories." These are a singular technical entity, born from ARPANET
(the US), an occurrence of many smaller systems independent of each other and a
system of governance and control.
body:
An essay about "the strengths and limitations of three broad ways of framing
Internet histories." These are a singular technical entity, born from ARPANET
(the US), an occurrence of many smaller systems independent of each other and a
system of governance and control. 

It's argued that the internet is a cultural artefact as much as it is a
technological system. We see this in the way different cultures and societies
engage with the internet. This comes through historical cultural values as well
as socio-economic factors, which includes internet access, speeds, consumer
hardware, free time to spend online and governmental control.

Importance is placed on the value of understanding the internet as a shared
development rather than a singular technological entity born from the US.

> p. 2 The spread and adoption of the internet has been documented differently
> by different cultures.

> p.3 Once learned, infrastructures become invisible until they break or falter,
> after which they are painfully visible again.  

> p. 4 Cybersyn was a nationally networked computer infrastructure in Chile
> 1971. It existed before ARPANET and shows that the internet is not a
> technology that exclusively comes from the US. 

> p.3 Stating that online communities are largely formed out of privilege of
> free time and money for paid memberships. This is a bit out of touch. Back in
> the day, this was the case for sure. But in the modern day, I would argue
> (without having any qualitative proof) that it's he upper classes that will
> spend less time online as they have more money to enjoy sports, events, trips
> away and other such entertainments. They may well still be on their phones
> during that time, but the critical mass have a smartphone now. 

> p. 5 The geographical coverage of the internet follows patterns of power
> disparities. Something that [James Bridle](../g/5m5r) writes about in [New Dark Age - James Bridle](7gt0). 

> p. 6 To see the internet as a collection of local systems interfaced together,
> is to see the internet as multiple. Within each local net can exist a
> different relationship with internet both for users, providers and regulators. 

> p.7 A moral high ground has been created through the adoption of an ideology
> that the US are the "founders" of the internet. But in essence, the internet
> is a system of decentralised structures. It also came to be through this same
> phenomena, [decentralisation](../g/7hzl). 
---
> Using terminology like "internet histories" rather than "histories of the
> internet" helps shift the focus away from a singular technological entity, to
> a myriad of cultural manifestations.

---
References:

- Abbate, Janet. ‚ÄúWhat and Where Is the Internet? (Re)Defining Internet
  Histories.‚Äù Internet Histories 1, no. 1‚Äì2 (January 2, 2017): 8‚Äì14.
  https://doi.org/10.1080/24701475.2017.1305836.
snippets:
An essay about "the strengths and limitations of three broad ways of framing
Internet histories." These are a singular technical entity, born from ARPANET
(the US), an occurrence of many smaller systems independent of each other and a
system of governance and control.

title: "What and where is the Internet? (Re)defining Internet histories"

An essay about "the strengths and limitations of three broad ways of framing
Internet histories." These are a singular technical entity, born from ARPANET
(the US), an occurrence of many smaller systems independent of each other and a
system of governance and control. 

It's argued that the internet is a cultural artefact as much as it is a
technological system. We see this in the way different cultures and societies
engage with the internet. This comes through historical cultural values as well
as socio-economic factors, which includes internet access, speeds, consumer
hardware, free time to spend online and governmental control.

Importance is placed on the value of understanding the internet as a shared
development rather than a singular technological entity born from the US.

> p. 2 The spread and adoption of the internet has been documented differently
> by different cultures.

> p.3 Once learned, infrastructures become invisible until they break or falter,
> after which they are painfully visible again.  

> p. 4 Cybersyn was a nationally networked computer infrastructure in Chile
> 1971. It existed before ARPANET and shows that the internet is not a
> technology that exclusively comes from the US. 

> p.3 Stating that online communities are largely formed out of privilege of
> free time and money for paid memberships. This is a bit out of touch. Back in
> the day, this was the case for sure. But in the modern day, I would argue
> (without having any qualitative proof) that it's he upper classes that will
> spend less time online as they have more money to enjoy sports, events, trips
> away and other such entertainments. They may well still be on their phones
> during that time, but the critical mass have a smartphone now. 

> p. 5 The geographical coverage of the internet follows patterns of power
> disparities. Something that [James Bridle](../g/5m5r) writes about in [New Dark Age - James Bridle](7gt0). 

> p. 6 To see the internet as a collection of local systems interfaced together,
> is to see the internet as multiple. Within each local net can exist a
> different relationship with internet both for users, providers and regulators. 

> p.7 A moral high ground has been created through the adoption of an ideology
> that the US are the "founders" of the internet. But in essence, the internet
> is a system of decentralised structures. It also came to be through this same
> phenomena, [decentralisation](../g/7hzl). 
---
> Using terminology like "internet histories" rather than "histories of the
> internet" helps shift the focus away from a singular technological entity, to
> a myriad of cultural manifestations.

---
References:

- Abbate, Janet. ‚ÄúWhat and Where Is the Internet? (Re)Defining Internet
  Histories.‚Äù Internet Histories 1, no. 1‚Äì2 (January 2, 2017): 8‚Äì14.
  https://doi.org/10.1080/24701475.2017.1305836.

title: Why Open Source Misses the Point of Free Software - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation
link: [Why Open Source Misses the Point of Free Software - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation](r/p6ou)
lead: # Why Open Source Misses the Point of Free Software - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation
body:
# Why Open Source Misses the Point of Free Software - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation

"free software" means:
> "the freedom to run it, to study and change it, and to redistribute copies
> with or without changes. This is a matter of freedom, not price, so think of
> ‚Äúfree speech,‚Äù not ‚Äúfree beer.""

> these freedoms are vitally important. They're essential, not just for the
> user's sake but for society and democracy as a whole as they promote social
> solidarity - meaning sharing and cooperation.

> open source detracts from the FOSS cause, as it does not have complete
> freedom of the user at the forefront of its intentions. 

---
References:

- https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/open-source-misses-the-point.en.html

it the hardest.

People are using the newfound ability to discredit an image as AI generated
content as a shortcut to confirming their own beliefs.

# Your Work is Not Your God

About how burnout is the result of believing that work is what brings purpose to
ourselves. But in fact this modern belief fules itself, where each
accomplishment matters less than your constant effort toward the *next*
accomplisment. 

> Engagement is not about stepping back, though. It‚Äôs about immersion. When
> performing a procedure, surgeons do work that lends itself to the experience
> of ‚Äúflow‚Äù. As the late psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi described them,
> people in flow states shut out the world and their own bodily needs, forgoing
> food and sleep as they do something that seems good for its own sake. It‚Äôs
> a state of engagement that video game designers try to foster, because it
> makes the game hard to quit.


References:

- https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/06/burnout-epidemic-work-lives-meaning

title: Zettelkasten Method - Youtube
lead:
1 box for reference
1 box for thoughts
body:
1 box for reference
1 box for thoughts

## Step 1 - Take Literature Notes

Keep notes short, be selective and write them in your own words.

## Step 2 - Take Reference Notes

Take bibliographical / reference notes about the source (ie where to find the
info that inspired the thought)

## Step 3 - Make Permanent Notes

Go through each note from that info source. 
Make connections between what you learned and what you know. 
This creates more hooks to connect new information too.

### [Find Meaningful Connections](../ma31)

1. How does this idea fit into what I know?
2. Can this be explained by something else?
3. What does X mean for Y?
4. How can I use this idea to explain Z?

This is the 'itegration' layer as part of the [layers of evidence](../r/mulf)
principle.

### Finding Keywords

Note: This is relating to a keyword zettel, like a book index. Against each 
keyword are a few different representational notes of the keyword. This concept 
should *never* be applied to the practice of tagging. 

It's not about knowing where to store the note, it's about: 
- deciding in which circumstances do I want to stumble upon this note?
- When and how will I use this idea?

Keywords should be assigned in relation to the overall topic you are working on
with that idea and never by considering the note in isolation. 

## Fleeting Notes

Ideas that pop into your mind. 
Review them within a few days and turn them into new seeds if inspired to. 

---
References:

- [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/embed/rOSZOCoqOo8)

# Zettelkasten Method - Youtube

1 box for reference
1 box for thoughts

## Step 1 - Take Literature Notes

Keep notes short, be selective and write them in your own words.

## Step 2 - Take Reference Notes

Take bibliographical / reference notes about the source (ie where to find the
info that inspired the thought)

## Step 3 - Make Permanent Notes

Go through each note from that info source. 
Make connections between what you learned and what you know. 
This creates more hooks to connect new information too.

### [Find Meaningful Connections](../ma31)

1. How does this idea fit into what I know?
2. Can this be explained by something else?
3. What does X mean for Y?
4. How can I use this idea to explain Z?

This is the 'itegration' layer as part of the [layers of evidence](../r/mulf)
principle.

### Finding Keywords

Note: This is relating to a keyword zettel, like a book index. Against each 
keyword are a few different representational notes of the keyword. This concept 
should *never* be applied to the practice of tagging. 

It's not about knowing where to store the note, it's about: 
- deciding in which circumstances do I want to stumble upon this note?
- When and how will I use this idea?

Keywords should be assigned in relation to the overall topic you are working on
with that idea and never by considering the note in isolation. 

## Fleeting Notes

Ideas that pop into your mind. 
Review them within a few days and turn them into new seeds if inspired to.

title: advertising model
lead:
The advertising profit model solidifies the intent to sell the user, rather than
sell to the user. The average per user, per quarter value of a user to Facebook
is just under [$3 per month](https://www.statista.com/statistics/251328/facebooks-average-revenue-per-user-by-region/). Many
paid software products (open source and closed source) who do not rely on the
advertising model, sell their product for more. This begs the question, has the
amount of turmoil and damage that social media has caused been worth saving $3
per month? Clearly not.
body:
The advertising profit model solidifies the intent to sell the user, rather than
sell to the user. The average per user, per quarter value of a user to Facebook
is just under [$3 per month](https://www.statista.com/statistics/251328/facebooks-average-revenue-per-user-by-region/). Many
paid software products (open source and closed source) who do not rely on the
advertising model, sell their product for more. This begs the question, has the
amount of turmoil and damage that social media has caused been worth saving $3
per month? Clearly not.

Of course there are reasons for this measly $3 per month figure. It is in part
because US users are worth around three times more than users from Europe, and
even more from the rest of the world. But also simply because Facebook has
managed to acquire so many users. It achieved this by having the "right" idea at
the right time, but also due to the now infamous network effect. If they had
charged users from the beginning, it is safe to say the uptake would have been
slower and would probably never reached the levels they are today.

per month? Clearly not.

# advertising model

The advertising profit model solidifies the intent to sell the user, rather than
sell to the user. The average per user, per quarter value of a user to Facebook
is just under [$3 per month](https://www.statista.com/statistics/251328/facebooks-average-revenue-per-user-by-region/). Many
paid software products (open source and closed source) who do not rely on the
advertising model, sell their product for more. This begs the question, has the
amount of turmoil and damage that social media has caused been worth saving $3
per month? Clearly not.

Of course there are reasons for this measly $3 per month figure. It is in part
because US users are worth around three times more than users from Europe, and
even more from the rest of the world. But also simply because Facebook has
managed to acquire so many users. It achieved this by having the "right" idea at
the right time, but also due to the now infamous network effect. If they had
charged users from the beginning, it is safe to say the uptake would have been
slower and would probably never reached the levels they are today.

title: an argument against moving data centres to remote far northern areas to take advantage of "free cooling", is network latency
link: [an argument against moving data centres to remote far northern areas to take advantage of "free cooling", is network latency](xbnb)
lead:
A pretty poor excuse. Most of the world have terrible latency already, so it
would only be those in the US who would notice the difference.
body:
A pretty poor excuse. Most of the world have terrible latency already, so it
would only be those in the US who would notice the difference.

These are the exact kind of scenarios where regulatory pressure would make these
changes a reality. If data centres were forced to pay a carbon tax high enough,
they may consider simply moving their centres to arctic countries to take
advantage of "free cooling" as they call it.

This would drastically reduce energy consumption, and work against making the
world hotter so that our servers can keep functioning - against a world that is
getting hotter.

Sometimes the ridiculousness of the approach to the climate crisis becomes
very apparent.

would only be those in the US who would notice the difference.

# an argument against moving data centres to remote far northern areas to take advantage of "free cooling", is network latency

A pretty poor excuse. Most of the world have terrible latency already, so it
would only be those in the US who would notice the difference.

These are the exact kind of scenarios where regulatory pressure would make these
changes a reality. If data centres were forced to pay a carbon tax high enough,
they may consider simply moving their centres to arctic countries to take
advantage of "free cooling" as they call it.

This would drastically reduce energy consumption, and work against making the
world hotter so that our servers can keep functioning - against a world that is
getting hotter.

Sometimes the ridiculousness of the approach to the climate crisis becomes
very apparent.

title: automagic improvements are a cause for confusion and suspicion
link: [automagic improvements are a cause for confusion and suspicion](v5qr)
lead: I had my laptop plugged into an external monitor. The computer would intermittently freeze. I could move the mouse, but not interact with anything or scroll. Then it froze for a long time, so I unplugged the monitor and my screen went blank. A restart I suppose as I was prompted to log back in and all my apps that I'd previously had open started to open.
body:
I had my laptop plugged into an external monitor. The computer would intermittently freeze. I could move the mouse, but not interact with anything or scroll. Then it froze for a long time, so I unplugged the monitor and my screen went blank. A restart I suppose as I was prompted to log back in and all my apps that I'd previously had open started to open.

Happens sometimes I guess; but then I noticed that my trackpad / pointer was reacting soooo much smoother. It felt great, like the computer had regained some sharpness in thought during its brief power nap. I was elated. An upgrade! Out of nowhere! Or was it? 
I didn't confirm any upgrade, it was a sudden restart. A bug. But why did my mouse behaviour change? 

It's so menial and strange, that it makes you suddenly a bit uneasy. Where you don't feel in control of your system anymore.

# automagic improvements are a cause for confusion and suspicion

I had my laptop plugged into an external monitor. The computer would intermittently freeze. I could move the mouse, but not interact with anything or scroll. Then it froze for a long time, so I unplugged the monitor and my screen went blank. A restart I suppose as I was prompted to log back in and all my apps that I'd previously had open started to open.

Happens sometimes I guess; but then I noticed that my trackpad / pointer was reacting soooo much smoother. It felt great, like the computer had regained some sharpness in thought during its brief power nap. I was elated. An upgrade! Out of nowhere! Or was it? 
I didn't confirm any upgrade, it was a sudden restart. A bug. But why did my mouse behaviour change? 

It's so menial and strange, that it makes you suddenly a bit uneasy. Where you don't feel in control of your system anymore.

title: chaos is constant, order is momentary and constantly renewed by the medium of the mind

lead:
> Life is a balance between chaos and order. In pure chaos, there is no order.
> In pure order, there is no chaos. 
> In pure chaos, there is no life.
> In pure order there is no life. 
> If every aspect of life is understood rationally, there is no life as it disregards the factor of chaos.
> If every aspect of life is regarded as chaos, then there is no understanding of life. 
> To understand life, one needs to understand chaos and order equally as one and the same.

title: companies are like organisms
lead: A nice quote from [Steve Yegge](g/t9nq) in one of his tech talks.
body:
A nice quote from [Steve Yegge](g/t9nq) in one of his tech talks.

It may well be a good strategy to really understand this when
moving into a software career. One thing that strikes immediately
true is the notion that the company doesn't really care about you,
they care about surviving.

People struggle with this in thinking that the company feels about them,
the way that they feel about the company. That they have a relationship
and that the relationship binds them, bringing with it care and consideration.

As Steve also says, that may be true within teams, but at the broadest scale of
the company, this is far from the truth (the larger the company, the more true).

An organism will kill and recycle cells without any consideration (it doesn't have
the faculty of consideration). It's goal is to survive, and if it needs to kill
cells to do this (starvation will eat the bodies own fat and muscle), it will.

This falls very much into the space of organisational psychology.
snippets: A nice quote from [Steve Yegge](g/t9nq) in one of his tech talks.

# companies are like organisms

A nice quote from [Steve Yegge](g/t9nq) in one of his tech talks.

It may well be a good strategy to really understand this when
moving into a software career. One thing that strikes immediately
true is the notion that the company doesn't really care about you,
they care about surviving.

People struggle with this in thinking that the company feels about them,
the way that they feel about the company. That they have a relationship
and that the relationship binds them, bringing with it care and consideration.

As Steve also says, that may be true within teams, but at the broadest scale of
the company, this is far from the truth (the larger the company, the more true).

An organism will kill and recycle cells without any consideration (it doesn't have
the faculty of consideration). It's goal is to survive, and if it needs to kill
cells to do this (starvation will eat the bodies own fat and muscle), it will.

This falls very much into the space of organisational psychology.

title: copyright
lead:
> A **copyright** is a type of intellectual property that gives its owner the exclusive right to copy, distribute, adapt, display, and perform a creative work, usually for a limited time. The creative work may be in a literary, artistic, educational, or musical form. Copyright is intended to protect the original expression of an idea in the form of a creative work, but not the idea itself. A copyright is subject to limitations based on public interest considerations, such as the fair use doctrine in the United States.
> [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright)

title: data lineage
lead:
> **data lineage** includes the data origin, what happens to it, and where it moves over time. Data lineage provides visibility and simplifies tracing errors back to the root cause in a data analytics process.It also enables replaying specific portions or inputs of the data flow for step-wise debugging or regenerating lost output. Database systems use such information, called data provenance, to address similar validation and debugging challenges. Data provenance refers to records of the inputs, entities, systems, and processes that influence data of interest, providing a historical record of the data and its origins. The generated evidence supports forensic activities such as data-dependency analysis, error/compromise detection and recovery, auditing, and compliance analysis. "Lineage is a simple type of why provenance."Data lineage can be represented visually to discover the data flow/movement from its source to destination via various changes and hops on its way in the enterprise environment, how the data gets transformed along the way, how the representation and parameters change, and how the data splits or converges after each hop. A simple representation of the Data Lineage can be shown with dots and lines, where dot represents a data container for data points and lines connecting them represents the transformations the data point undergoes, between the data containers.
>
> [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data%20lineage)

title: dreams and stories
lead: # dreams and stories
body:

title: fediverse
lead:
The fediverse is the sum of all software that's built on [ActivityPub](mg2u),
a protocol standard set by the w3c for developing decentralised social networks.
body:
The fediverse is the sum of all software that's built on [ActivityPub](mg2u),
a protocol standard set by the w3c for developing decentralised social networks.   

All software in the fediverse has the ability to communicate with each other by
means of a json string - [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ActivityPub).  

Since the beginning of Twitter's apparent downfall, as well as general sentiment
amongst the public of social media, software like Mastodon have seen
a strong uptake in users. 

In [The Changelog Podcast - 528](https://changelog.com/podcast/528), Even
Prodromou talks about the current outlook of the Fediverse as well as the
challenges it faces. 

One interesting point is the fact that, in the case of Mastodon as the
example, instances have the risk of becoming quasi-centralized in that the
maintainer not only adopts an air of importance and command of the server, its
users and it's culture to a degree, but that maintainer can also burn out and
close the server. 

One of the benefits of a decentralized network however, is that those users can
simply make an account on new instance. This is made possible by Mastodon being
built on the [ActivityPub](mg2u) protocol, allowing export and import of data and
connections between services.

[Bluesky](https://blueskyweb.org/) is a new (2023-10-06) decentralised social
media platform, but built on their own [AT Protocol](https://atproto.com/)
