# fediverse

The fediverse is the sum of all software that's built on [ActivityPub](mg2u),
a protocol standard set by the w3c for developing decentralised social networks.   

All software in the fediverse has the ability to communicate with each other by
means of a json string - [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ActivityPub).  

Since the beginning of Twitter's apparent downfall, as well as general sentiment
amongst the public of social media, software like Mastodon have seen
a strong uptake in users. 

In [The Changelog Podcast - 528](https://changelog.com/podcast/528), Even
Prodromou talks about the current outlook of the Fediverse as well as the
challenges it faces. 

One interesting point is the fact that, in the case of Mastodon as the
example, instances have the risk of becoming quasi-centralized in that the
maintainer not only adopts an air of importance and command of the server, its
users and it's culture to a degree, but that maintainer can also burn out and
close the server. 

One of the benefits of a decentralized network however, is that those users can
simply make an account on new instance. This is made possible by Mastodon being
built on the [ActivityPub](mg2u) protocol, allowing export and import of data and
connections between services.

[Bluesky](https://blueskyweb.org/) is a new (2023-10-06) decentralised social
media platform, but built on their own [AT Protocol](https://atproto.com/)

title: first Vipassana retreat
lead: ## Vipassana
body:
## Vipassana

Vipassana is the original, unaltered meditation technique of "The Buddha" (as we were
taught, any enlightened person is Buddha), Siddhartha Gautama. It is a practice
of meditation that is universal in that everyone has access to it. You don't
need to pay someone to provide you with your own special mantra (no access for
the poor), to visualise an image (no access for the blind), or to sit or move
in any particular way (no access for physically challenged). The technique is
grounded in experiencing the present moment through observation of bodily
sensations, something that everyone has access to [^1].

The following is my understanding of the philosophies of Vipassana meditation
and how they interface with our daily life and nature as a whole.
As context, you can read a text [here](https://www.dhamma.org/en/about/art) based on a
talk by [S.N Goenka](https://www.dhamma.org/en/about/goenka), who was a leader
in the teaching of Vipassana from 1969-2013. 

I comment a little bit on the ten day course I completed in June 2023, but in
keeping with the correct way of introducing people to the course - I do not
want to influence too much or create too much of an image.

The TL;DR for the Vipassana course itself is that it was mentally and
physically challenging but very educational and rewarding. The two advices I would give is 1)
anyone considering to undertake a course should first establish a 
practice of regular mindfulness meditation and be comfortable to sit on the ground
with legs crossed. This is more so that you can take best advantage of the
unique experience and environment of a Vipassana course, and not have to spend
all your time battling physical discomfort. And 2) to just wait until you feel like it's 
a good time to do it. There's no need to rush. It will pay off much more if it's done 
when it wants to be done.

## The Retreat

I did my course in Sweden at [Dhamma Sobhana](https://sobhana.dhamma.org/).
The environment was a manifestation of tranquility itself. To be found were
well kept gardens, small forest areas with varieties of beautiful flowers,
winding paths and cosy red cottages with white outlines. Time is defined by the
soft striking of two gongs. One for the male students, another for the female,
a perfect fourth interval apart, creating a slowly phasing ambient rhythm that
is heard anywhere in the compound. Beds are comfortable, food is wholesome and
amenities just fine. 

The noble silence was an interesting and special experience. On the arrival
day, you meet everyone and can get to know each other, then from 20:00 the
noble silence begins. The nine days that follow you may not talk or communicate
with other students in any way. No gesturing, writing or signalling. This helps
a lot with being able to stay in the meditational focus and frame of mind
required to make the meditation sessions more fluid. It also reduces the mental
friction that can occur if students compare their experiences with each other
throughout the week. This can lead to comparison between ones self and others,
which has no useful place in meditational practice at all. The meditation is
your experience. The yard stick is your equanimity. 

The most profound thing about the silence though is, upon the last day when the
silence is lifted, how much more you know each other despite not having talked
since day one. Everyone feels like close friends. This no doubt comes through
the sharing of the challenging experience, and living in close quarters with
each other. It was very interesting to experience how a strong sense of solidarity 
and friendship can still occur in near total lack of communication, vocal or otherwise. 

I considered a few times that it could be an interesting exercise for teams of 
software developers to spend some days (maybe not ten) in a retreat, where they cannot 
communicate with each other at all, but need to live together and also work on a programming 
task. The value would lie in the interpersonal and social developments that come from a form 
of interaction that is outside of the normal and mundane (like the uncomfortable exercise 
of two people being tasked to stare for two minutes directly into each others eyes without 
averting their gazes. Anyone who's done this, realises a strange sense of 'knowing' the person afterward, 
despite having exchanged no words). 

Vipassana retreats can be anywhere from three days to fourty-five. Ten days 
is the standard and recommended length. During these ten days, you essentially 
live the life of a monk or nun. You don't speak, you eat the food that is prepared 
for you and you follow a set schedule of meditation and break times. 

It's demanding, physically and mentally. Eleven hours meditation every day
requires the body to be accustomed to sitting on the floor without unbearable
or increasing discomfort. And to focus continuously for ten days is strenuous
in of itself, despite the focus not being on an analytical task. You do
encounter then, a form of mental exhaustion, and it's made worse when you
indulge in questioning how many days are left and how difficult will those days
increasingly be. But this is just as much part of the practice. To disengage
from those thoughts of aversion and craving, and the tension they bring, and to
return to the true reality of you being where you are, moment to moment.

## The Technique

On the forth day the main Vipassana technique, Pa√±√±a, is taught. It's the
practice of observing sensations in the body and remaining equanimous with
them. This means to not judge them as being pleasurable or unpleasurable,
desirable or undesirable, wanted or unwanted. By practicing this equanimity,
the behavioural pattern of the mind, which seeks to generate craving (pleasure)
and aversion (displeasure), becomes weakened. The generation of craving or
aversion leads to attachment; we become attached to something desirable
happening, or something undesirable not happening. When the opposite happens,
and what we want to happen does not eventuate, we encounter misery. 

With this, Buddha concluded that craving and aversion are the root cause of all
misery and to become fully enlightened, one must rid themselves of all craving
and aversion. At this point, a lot of people get demotivated from the
philosophy. *This is a path only for some*. The rest of us can move somewhere
along the path and stop at whatever point is sustainable. That is the best
collective result for society. It does not need to be all or nothing. You 
can still have sex (even with yourself), or do <insert naughty thing>. The idea 
is to become a *better* person, not to become Buddha. You can actually bake the cake 
and eat it too in this case, you just wont assimilate into the universe.

Vipassana teaches that each and every reaction we elicit, mental or physical,
begins with a sensation in the body. The sensations in the body arise from the
unconscious mind, that is its domain; the autonomous faculties of mind and
matter. By training ourselves to calm our outer layer, the conscious mind, and
to maintain awareness of bodily sensations as they rise and pass away, we are
training an ability to integrate an awareness into our every day life. When we
subsequently find ourselves in any situation, and we have a good practice of
Vipassana established (being equanimous), we can become aware of a sensation in
the body as they occur. With the awareness of that sensation, we can then react
more wisely than we otherwise would, as our reactions otherwise would be just
that - reactions, not considerations. 

## Anicca, The Law of Impermanence

From this comes the emergence of a compassion for all life an all beings,
because all life, including ourselves, exists within the same universal law of
impermanence. All things change. Because all things change, all things are
impermanent, ultimate truth cannot exist in the generation of craving or
aversion. Craving *can* remain permanent, as can aversion. They feed themselves
and only grow more hungry. This is incongruous with the universal law of
impermanence. It places you on a divergent path to that of true nature, which
ultimately generates misery for you, as you are diverging yourself from nature.  

Generating craving or aversion (sankahra) is the process of desiring reality to
be something it is not. Vipassana teaches the practitioner to observe reality
as it is, which brings tranquility and peace to the experience of reality. This
does not mean that we can't desire things. Or that if we desire things or want
things to be different, that we will only generate misery. Of course in
essence, it does work this way and becomes clearer when you take the extreme as
an example: If you always desire a different reality than your own, then your
reality will be misery, because day after day, year after year it is not what
you want. This is a disease that plagues many people who are focussed on
generating wealth and power for the sake of wealth and power. It leads to never
being satisfied, because there is always more to be had. Drug addiction
works the same, it's just the object of the craving is different. 

We can still desire things, and to be excited about things eventuating. **The
measure of how much misery this brings to your life is how much tension you
experience waiting for the thing to eventuate and how equanimous you remain
when that desire does not eventuate.** If you experience no tension while
waiting for the thing to eventuate; meaning you are present in each moment up
until it eventuates or not, and if you do not react with frustration, anger,
disappointment or such when it does not eventuate; then you are living a life
closer to real peace and harmony. A life of equanimity. 

Pure Vipassana theory would say that you should also not experience elation or
euphoria when the thing *does* occur. On the outset, this does not sound
appropriate. However, feeling elation, euphoria or other such extreme
"positive" feelings, are the *result* of a craving being satisfied. If you were
to feel elation, euphoria or such feelings when the thing eventuates, you would
equally feel devastation, anger, resentment or such feelings if it did not
eventuate. With each action there is an equal and opposite reaction. 

## A Sense of Realism?

It is however important to remember that nature and life could not exist
without sankahra. Reproduction is fuelled by sankahra. Nature is perfect, but
also imperfect. It is cruel and kind. We can also not simply conclude that a
life completely void of sankahra which an enlightened person achieves, should
be hailed as the true destination of happiness and prosperity for all humans. If all
humans achieved this, we would stop reproducing. It would be an extinction
event. However, it would arguably be better for all other beings and plants
on earth if humans became extinct. Everything else suffers by our existence (except 
viruses). 

The paradox here I suppose is that if all humans did become enlightened, no one
would have a problem with the human race becoming extinct within a generation,
as we would all be one with nature anyway. We would be totally and collectively
at peace with death and the ultimate truth of nature, meaning we would not be
compelled to reproduce - a partial process of immortalising ourselves by passing
fragments of ourselves down to our children. 

At this point it is theory. Just reading the concepts can never lead to an
accurate conclusion of its truth. It needs to be experienced itself. And this
comes full circle to the essence of the Vipassana technique being a universal
truth. It is a practice that is universally true for each and every human
being. The practice is to experience one's own reality as it is, not as one
wishes it to be. There is no exclusivity in the accessibility to this truth or
ultimately to enlightenment. It is universal, and nature is universal. No one
is more or less resultant from nature than anyone else. Anyone can experience
the benefits of Vipassana because everyone has universal access to the truth of
nature through the manifestation of sensations of the body.

As mentioned above, this is different from other modifications of the technique
such as transcendental meditation, which requires the practitioner be given a
mantra. A special and supposedly unique word, which only a guru can give. The
provision of this mantra, carries the burden of secrecy whereby the
practitioner cannot reveal the mantra to anyone else, or else the mantra will
loose its essence. While using the mantra as a source of focus for meditation
does calm and focus the mind, it does not allow the practitioner to access the
pure truth of themselves and their place in nature. This is because they are
themselves generating an alternate reality for themselves by repeating a secret
word. This by definition is *not* a universal truth. If each practitioner of
transcendental meditation is given a unique word, then each practitioner is
experiencing a reality that is divergent from their true reality when they
meditate, the reality as it is, not as they (through repetition of mantra) wish
it to be. By diverging from nature in a meditational practice, one can never
truly access nature at its core. Only the surface, a calming of the mind and an
enhanced focus, will be reached. 


[^1] I did some research for cases where people may lose the ability to perceive 
all perception of sensations in the body, but did not find anything. Only partial loss in sensation. 
If I'm wrong, please email me!

title: gender inequality is in part supported by undiagnosed autism in men
link: [gender inequality is in part supported by undiagnosed autism in men](v9za)
lead:
Consider some common traits of autism; lack of empathy, short temper, poor
communication and social skills and a requirement for rigid structure and order
in the environment. When coupled with the disparity in physical strength that
men have, it's seemingly clear why autism as a disorder has contributed to the
establishment of gender inequality.
body:
Consider some common traits of autism; lack of empathy, short temper, poor
communication and social skills and a requirement for rigid structure and order
in the environment. When coupled with the disparity in physical strength that
men have, it's seemingly clear why autism as a disorder has contributed to the
establishment of gender inequality.

It's also interesting to see how the advent of autism research and diagnosis has
coincided with the growth of gender inequality as an issue, and female rights.

title: inflation
lead:
> Inflation is a measure of the rate of rising prices of goods and services in
> an economy.
body:
> Inflation is a measure of the rate of rising prices of goods and services in
> an economy.

Cost-Push Inflation: 

Results from production cost increase (material costs, wage rises, etc). The
price of the product then needs to increase (inflate) as well. 

Demand-Pull Inflation:

Strong consumer demand for a product, increasing the accepted price to pay. This
can either be for a desirable item, which is typically short lived
inflation. Follows the structure of supply and demand. A more widespread factor is consumer confidence. This occurs when
unemployment rate is low and/or wages are rising.

Central banks aim to control inflation with monetary policy including interest rates.

> Interest rates are increased to make borrowing more difficult, which slows
> down the economy and decreases inflation

# inflation

> Inflation is a measure of the rate of rising prices of goods and services in
> an economy.

Cost-Push Inflation: 

Results from production cost increase (material costs, wage rises, etc). The
price of the product then needs to increase (inflate) as well. 

Demand-Pull Inflation:

Strong consumer demand for a product, increasing the accepted price to pay. This
can either be for a desirable item, which is typically short lived
inflation. Follows the structure of supply and demand. A more widespread factor is consumer confidence. This occurs when
unemployment rate is low and/or wages are rising.

Central banks aim to control inflation with monetary policy including interest rates.

> Interest rates are increased to make borrowing more difficult, which slows
> down the economy and decreases inflation

title: innovator's dilemma
lead:
> "The innovator‚Äôs dilemma comes from the book of the same title by Clayton Christerenses. The dilemma is this: a large, market-leading company has some motivation to innovate, but also a strong disincentive as well, because innovation risks undermining its existing products."
> - The Pragmatic Engineer newsletter on Bun
body:
> "The innovator‚Äôs dilemma comes from the book of the same title by Clayton Christerenses. The dilemma is this: a large, market-leading company has some motivation to innovate, but also a strong disincentive as well, because innovation risks undermining its existing products."
> - The Pragmatic Engineer newsletter on Bun

It's because of the innovator's dilemma, that startups can exist and new tech is developed. Startups or innovators in general do not carry the risk of undermining their own products and users. They can start with a clean slate where they may support 90% of some dependant technology and it's user's projects, but break the other 10% of projects / use cases. 

As is in the example of Bun / Node.js. Bun has drastically innovated the JavaScript runtime, delivering incredible speed performances.

This concept should then really be more accurately titled "the dilemma to innovate pre-established technologies carrying personal commitment"

lead: > ... missing quote from ref
body:
> ... missing quote from ref

This encapsulates really well how technology comes to exist. It is at all times
a response by the constant undulation of societal development. For example,
currently we can see a movement towards a greater value and need for privacy,
security and decentralisation online. 

This has come from the corruption that social media has introduced to our
social interactions as well as the sudden downfall of Twitter, which has
created a surge of interest in federated platforms like Mastodon. 

The decentralised communication protocol Matrix is also gathering momentum.
Hivron Stenhav, my lab parter from Language Based Security at KTH who is
currently doing her masters thesis at the Swedish Cyersecurity Agency on the
protocol, tells me that a few countries are already or are seriously
considering using it for their internal government communications.

title: moonlander diary
lead:
## observations
- previous keyboard shortcuts become highly incompatible
- placing modifier keys defines the rest of the layers as well as they theoretically should remain accessible
- definitely need to move slowly. First cover the basics - setup every basic key  that is needed, then start to think about modifiers
- having modifier keys on hold under regular keys is super nice. eg `cmd` is underneath both 'a' and 'l' so my fingers are always on top of the command modifier when I need it! 
- reusing keys through layers may help to enforce muscle memory. eg, using the forward slash from layer 0 for divide on the numpad 
- theres alays going to be tradeoffs. eg mapping cmd on hold to all letters makes keyboard shortcuts less 'responsive', such as screen changing. Although screen changing will be mapped to the hyper key in the future (it also broke my vim exit bindking of kj)
body:
## observations
- previous keyboard shortcuts become highly incompatible
- placing modifier keys defines the rest of the layers as well as they theoretically should remain accessible
- definitely need to move slowly. First cover the basics - setup every basic key  that is needed, then start to think about modifiers
- having modifier keys on hold under regular keys is super nice. eg `cmd` is underneath both 'a' and 'l' so my fingers are always on top of the command modifier when I need it! 
- reusing keys through layers may help to enforce muscle memory. eg, using the forward slash from layer 0 for divide on the numpad 
- theres alays going to be tradeoffs. eg mapping cmd on hold to all letters makes keyboard shortcuts less 'responsive', such as screen changing. Although screen changing will be mapped to the hyper key in the future (it also broke my vim exit bindking of kj)

After 1.5 months I'm back to the same typing speed on words. Haven't tested numbers yet, but I must be faster (when included with words due to number pad layer)

Jan 24th. Haven't touched the layout in about a month. So it seems pretty settled. 
In total it took be about 2-3 months to get to a solid layout that works for me and to get my typing speed back to before.

###### SEE ALSO
---

# moonlander diary

## observations
- previous keyboard shortcuts become highly incompatible
- placing modifier keys defines the rest of the layers as well as they theoretically should remain accessible
- definitely need to move slowly. First cover the basics - setup every basic key  that is needed, then start to think about modifiers
- having modifier keys on hold under regular keys is super nice. eg `cmd` is underneath both 'a' and 'l' so my fingers are always on top of the command modifier when I need it! 
- reusing keys through layers may help to enforce muscle memory. eg, using the forward slash from layer 0 for divide on the numpad 
- theres alays going to be tradeoffs. eg mapping cmd on hold to all letters makes keyboard shortcuts less 'responsive', such as screen changing. Although screen changing will be mapped to the hyper key in the future (it also broke my vim exit bindking of kj)

After 1.5 months I'm back to the same typing speed on words. Haven't tested numbers yet, but I must be faster (when included with words due to number pad layer)

Jan 24th. Haven't touched the layout in about a month. So it seems pretty settled. 
In total it took be about 2-3 months to get to a solid layout that works for me and to get my typing speed back to before.

title: multitasking
lead:
Multitasking does not actually exist. It's the term we've given to being able to
shift our attention very fast between multiple focal points. People who say they
are "good multitaskers" are in fact under the guise of [The mere-exposure
effect](../5zlo).
body:
Multitasking does not actually exist. It's the term we've given to being able to
shift our attention very fast between multiple focal points. People who say they
are "good multitaskers" are in fact under the guise of [The mere-exposure
effect](../5zlo).

Multitasking uses more [floating attention](irfi).

# multitasking

Multitasking does not actually exist. It's the term we've given to being able to
shift our attention very fast between multiple focal points. People who say they
are "good multitaskers" are in fact under the guise of [The mere-exposure
effect](../5zlo).

Multitasking uses more [floating attention](irfi).

title: noise pollution
lead:
> **noise pollution**, or sound pollution, is the propagation of noise or sound with ranging impacts on the activity of human or animal life, most of which are harmful to a degree. The source of outdoor noise worldwide is mainly caused by machines, transport, and propagation systems. Poor urban planning may give rise to noise disintegration or pollution, side-by-side industrial and residential buildings can result in noise pollution in the residential areas. Some of the main sources of noise in residential areas include loud music, transportation (traffic, rail, airplanes, etc.), lawn care maintenance, construction, electrical generators, wind turbines, explosions, and people.
> [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noise%20pollution)

title: philosophy and benefit of open source
lead:
Open source allows the internet community to freely try a vast range of tools
without having to spend money in the process, allowing each user to develop
their own personal setup and functionalities suites to them and their specific
needs and workflow.
body:
Open source allows the internet community to freely try a vast range of tools
without having to spend money in the process, allowing each user to develop
their own personal setup and functionalities suites to them and their specific
needs and workflow. 

This encapsulates the true advantages offered by computers and the internet. 

While there can be the argument that open source hinders the profitability of
software development, and therefore its progress - that's really only a problem
for profit makers who are seeking profit.

The open source community rely on one another for their tools and pay one
another when they value some software - which is when they uncover an app that
suits their personal needs.

# philosophy and benefit of open source

Open source allows the internet community to freely try a vast range of tools
without having to spend money in the process, allowing each user to develop
their own personal setup and functionalities suites to them and their specific
needs and workflow. 

This encapsulates the true advantages offered by computers and the internet. 

While there can be the argument that open source hinders the profitability of
software development, and therefore its progress - that's really only a problem
for profit makers who are seeking profit.

The open source community rely on one another for their tools and pay one
another when they value some software - which is when they uncover an app that
suits their personal needs.

title: post-scarcity
lead:
> **post-scarcity** is a theoretical economic situation in which most goods can be produced in great abundance with minimal human labor needed, so that they become available to all very cheaply or even freely.Post-scarcity does not mean that scarcity has been eliminated for all goods and services but that all people can easily have their basic survival needs met along with some significant proportion of their desires for goods and services. Writers on the topic often emphasize that some commodities will remain scarce in a post-scarcity society.
>
> [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-scarcity)

title: quantified self
lead:
The quantified self is the behavior of collecting qualitative data on oneself.
This covers medical as well as interpretive observations: mood, spiritual
connectiveness, alcohole intake, etc.
body:
The quantified self is the behavior of collecting qualitative data on oneself.
This covers medical as well as interpretive observations: mood, spiritual
connectiveness, alcohole intake, etc. 

Tools allow us to easily do this. But does it allow a better sense of self or a
healthier behaviors? I believe that technology abstracts us from our spirit,
effectively disconnecting us from a level of sensetivity that reveals a lot,
but in an inheretly subjective manner. It can be logged, but the feeling gained
from that sensetivity will provide richer data than the analysis of a change
log can. 

What allows a more effective positive progression in habits or mood, awareness
of oneself or quantified data? There is a big pit fall in quantified data,
where if the system is not set up sufficiently, it may just show trends,
without much availability to analyse the relationships of those trends or which
external variables are affecting them. 


How can you develop a better sensetivity to the inner state of ones self? 

- meditation
- therapy
- psychadelic medicines
- Psychedelic Therapy

---
References:

- [Quantified Self to the Extreme](r/khzz)

This covers medical as well as interpretive observations: mood, spiritual
connectiveness, alcohole intake, etc.

# quantified self

The quantified self is the behavior of collecting qualitative data on oneself.
This covers medical as well as interpretive observations: mood, spiritual
connectiveness, alcohole intake, etc. 

Tools allow us to easily do this. But does it allow a better sense of self or a
healthier behaviors? I believe that technology abstracts us from our spirit,
effectively disconnecting us from a level of sensetivity that reveals a lot,
but in an inheretly subjective manner. It can be logged, but the feeling gained
from that sensetivity will provide richer data than the analysis of a change
log can. 

What allows a more effective positive progression in habits or mood, awareness
of oneself or quantified data? There is a big pit fall in quantified data,
where if the system is not set up sufficiently, it may just show trends,
without much availability to analyse the relationships of those trends or which
external variables are affecting them. 


How can you develop a better sensetivity to the inner state of ones self? 

- meditation
- therapy
- psychadelic medicines
- Psychedelic Therapy

---

- [Quantified Self to the Extreme](r/khzz)

title: scroll up or drag down
lead:
I think it's interesting how there is a very clear and often heated divide
between the use of the trackpad. Either dragging your fingers upwards scrolls
upwards, or it scrolls downwards.
body:
I think it's interesting how there is a very clear and often heated divide
between the use of the trackpad. Either dragging your fingers upwards scrolls
upwards, or it scrolls downwards.

The argument for the "draggers" is that it's the same as moving a physical piece
of paper. This simultaneous connection and difference between digital media
which represents physical media is explored in great detail in [Near Print and
Beyond Paper: Knowing by Pdf](r/99ax)

It's an interesting UX divide. Does it say something about the person? How they
see the world, how the see technology or how they relate to technology?

title: social media
lead:
Generally, this is the idea of virtual meeting places. Where people in meat
space can have a digital proxy, through which they can communicate with other
digital proxies. These proxies may or may not have a meat space host (in the
case of bots), or multiple proxies may share a singular host (in the case of
fake or troll accounts for phishing, stalking, [OSINT](uyrm) or harassment).
body:
Generally, this is the idea of virtual meeting places. Where people in meat
space can have a digital proxy, through which they can communicate with other
digital proxies. These proxies may or may not have a meat space host (in the
case of bots), or multiple proxies may share a singular host (in the case of
fake or troll accounts for phishing, stalking, [OSINT](uyrm) or harassment).

While it is a good idea, we have seen how the control of these spaces by
financially incentivised companies, has lead to the manipulation of society at
large. This is a profound argument for the [decentralisation](7hzl) of social
media.

# social media

Generally, this is the idea of virtual meeting places. Where people in meat
space can have a digital proxy, through which they can communicate with other
digital proxies. These proxies may or may not have a meat space host (in the
case of bots), or multiple proxies may share a singular host (in the case of
fake or troll accounts for phishing, stalking, [OSINT](uyrm) or harassment).

While it is a good idea, we have seen how the control of these spaces by
financially incentivised companies, has lead to the manipulation of society at
large. This is a profound argument for the [decentralisation](7hzl) of social
media.

# terminal vs gui

- GUIs are abstractions of the terminal. 
- Doing as much in the terminal as possible reduces visual coginitive overload and
  context switching
- It's easier to do more effective processes, both computationally and functionally
  (without a mouse).

title: the barbell method of reading
lead: # the barbell method of reading
body:
# the barbell method of reading

A technique of reading that addresses two main problems:

1. reading a lot, but not processing the information
2. reading less, but wasting our time and energy on books of meagre value to us

Information is an opportunity, it means nothing if we don't use it.

## Steps to execute

1. Read the book swiftly, skipping parts only if they "make you vomit or put you
   to sleep". Mark the passages of interest.
2. Read the book a second time, but only read the marked passages. As you read
   them, process them as notes in the Zettelkasten.

A text contains four different types of mark opportunities:

1. Useful and difficult to understand. Mark these for later
2. Useful and easy to understand. Mark these for later
3. Not useful but difficult to understand. We don't actually want to process
   these, but mark and return to them later to understand this. Doing this will
   sharpen our mental teeth
4. Not useful and easy to understand. Ignore these

Highlighting and moving on also avoids noting down questions pre-emptively (as questions can
and often will be answered later in the paper. Taking time out to write them
down will take time and also has the potential to distract us from reading by
taking us on a separate thought trail within the Zettelkasten). I've found that re-reading the
highlights after having read the full paper, creates much stronger literature
notes and better and more relevant questions.

This technique and order of process is quite different to how Luhmann wrote
literature notes ([p.293](hptn)).

---

References:

- https://zettelkasten.de/posts/barbell-method-reading/
snippets: # the barbell method of reading

---

title: the efficacy of open source stems from the problems of others
link: [the efficacy of open source stems from the problems of others](076k)
lead: # the efficacy of open source stems from the problems of others
body:
# the efficacy of open source stems from the problems of others 

A very large part of your solutions will come from others who have had the same
or similar problem and received help. The fact that this is documented and open
(stack overflow, etc) is as much a part of open source as writing code
collaboratively.

But how does this differ from online forums in general? There people also have
problems and offer help.

There is an ingrained culture of collective production and volunteering in
software development. I think Zach Latta mentions this in his Changlog episode
(ep. 536).

**revisit: 2023-09-26**

Open source is the sharing of knowledge as commons
[Decentralisation: A multidisciplinary perspective](r/muqo). In a sense then,
the "source" that is "open" is also the openness to share thoughts, shared
experiences and problems. Through this, we help others.

So open source in terms of a license or code base, does not differ so much from
online forums in general, as questioned above.
snippets: # the efficacy of open source stems from the problems of others

title: this person does not exist
lead:
www.thispersondoesnotexist.com
www.thishorsedoesnotexist.com
body:
www.thispersondoesnotexist.com
www.thishorsedoesnotexist.com 

Technology that we rely on, can shape and form our reality in a way where we
can't tell the difference between what's real and what isnt. In some instances,
eg with photos, it is now impossible to tell. This creates a world where you
can never know what is real and what is fake. 

It puts you on edge and makes you untrustworthy of reality. You recede into
yourself and only belive and trust what feels right to you, which itself is a
manipulation of the system that we live in. 

Those feelings and those stimuli of what we believe are increasingly discovered
through digital services which rely on [algorithms](g/rggf) to deliver to you
the content - that ultimately has hidden intentions behind that particular
content being delivered to you.

Similar to themes of [Adam Curtis](g/64xb) and [New Dark Age - James Bridle](r/7gt0)

title: to-get-her
lead:
Another case of early establishment of patriarchal / misogynistic impressions
being made on children.
body:
Another case of early establishment of patriarchal / misogynistic impressions
being made on children.  

I remember in primary school learning how to spell "together". The teacher very
clearly explained that the word could be broken up into a mnemonic phrase
"to-get-her". I remember back then I was starting to have a weird interest in
girls (probably more so because I thought I had to because that's what the
grown ups do). The mystery of how this should happen, what it looks like, what
it should lead to was so think that I had no real reason to think twice about
the literal sense of the phrase "to-get-her". After all, as far as I
understood, that was what I was curious about doing it. 

To "get" (acquire) a person is not an acceptable thing to do in today's age.
Nor was it when I was back in primary school in the 1990s. But as a kid, you
don't comprehend these things. That is a societal learning that comes from your
environment, namely the adults in it. 

Moving forward without being aware of this, the idea to "get" the girl stayed
present and was indeed reinforced by media, music and society. It starts very
early, and is very pervasive...
snippets:
Another case of early establishment of patriarchal / misogynistic impressions
being made on children.
rawContent:
---
date: 2022-08-18 11:22
aliases:
tags: [me, seed]
---

# to-get-her

Another case of early establishment of patriarchal / misogynistic impressions
being made on children.  

I remember in primary school learning how to spell "together". The teacher very
clearly explained that the word could be broken up into a mnemonic phrase
"to-get-her". I remember back then I was starting to have a weird interest in
girls (probably more so because I thought I had to because that's what the
grown ups do). The mystery of how this should happen, what it looks like, what
it should lead to was so think that I had no real reason to think twice about
the literal sense of the phrase "to-get-her". After all, as far as I
understood, that was what I was curious about doing it. 

To "get" (acquire) a person is not an acceptable thing to do in today's age.
Nor was it when I was back in primary school in the 1990s. But as a kid, you
don't comprehend these things. That is a societal learning that comes from your
environment, namely the adults in it. 

Moving forward without being aware of this, the idea to "get" the girl stayed
present and was indeed reinforced by media, music and society. It starts very
early, and is very pervasive...

title: war of the cyber dynasties
lead:
FANG are the reigning dynasties of our time in cyberspace. Together they control
the majority of the internet landscape. But there is a force brewing that stands
to challenge their dominion. This is inline with the position that [we're
currently in a system of fudamislm, not capitalism](yoqs).
body:
FANG are the reigning dynasties of our time in cyberspace. Together they control
the majority of the internet landscape. But there is a force brewing that stands
to challenge their dominion. This is inline with the position that [we're
currently in a system of fudamislm, not capitalism](yoqs).

What we're seeing with internet services of the web 3.0 age, is a style of
grass roots resistance. These services or platforms, many built around
blockchain technologies, desire to build their own communities - but
critically - their own economies. This comes in the form of cryptocurrency,
whereby each service or platform has their own. 

With this, they build worth inside their own economy that exists within their
satellite town on the outskirts of FANG's kingdoms. [AI will become a commodity,
a moat around the castle](sjuw)

Could we see battles and borders of control shifting as we move more into
a decentralised or distributed internet? It could look a lot like the
skirmishes and battles of the middle ages. 

F, A, N and G could fall or at least have some power taken back from them, like
the Soviet Union, England and Germany saw.

grass roots resistance. These services or platforms, many built around

satellite town on the outskirts of FANG's kingdoms. [AI will become a commodity,
a moat around the castle](sjuw)

Could we see battles and borders of control shifting as we move more into
a decentralised or distributed internet? It could look a lot like the
skirmishes and battles of the middle ages. 

F, A, N and G could fall or at least have some power taken back from them, like
the Soviet Union, England and Germany saw.

title: what data engineers do
lead:
> "Data engineering is the development, implementation, and maintenance of
> systems and processes that take in raw data and produce high-quality,
> consistent information that supports downstream use cases, such as analysis
> and machine learning.  
>   
> Data engineering is the intersection of security, data management, DataOps,
> data architecture, orchestration, and software engineering. A data engineer
> manages the data engineering lifecycle, beginning with getting data from
> source systems and ending with serving data for use cases, such as analysis or
> machine learning."
body:
> "Data engineering is the development, implementation, and maintenance of
> systems and processes that take in raw data and produce high-quality,
> consistent information that supports downstream use cases, such as analysis
> and machine learning.  
>   
> Data engineering is the intersection of security, data management, DataOps,
> data architecture, orchestration, and software engineering. A data engineer
> manages the data engineering lifecycle, beginning with getting data from
> source systems and ending with serving data for use cases, such as analysis or
> machine learning."

Data engineers source data from systems, process, manage and supply it in
a digestible form for end user usage. This can be AI or customer interaction. 

Data engineers will work to translate sourced raw data into a [core data set](g/yb2a).

---

References: 

- [Fundamentals of Data Engineering](https://substack.com/redirect/29b68f10-0414-48f7-875f-afa54580bf1b?r=1a9yxf)

title: what is knowledge?
lead:
Knowledge is commonly understood from questioning truth. This boils down to
'factivity', as you can know if something is true or false. In both cases, you
know the truth. This is very much a philosophical view point. For this see,
[Knowledge - A Very Short Introduction](r/gv7e).
body:
Knowledge is commonly understood from questioning truth. This boils down to
'factivity', as you can know if something is true or false. In both cases, you
know the truth. This is very much a philosophical view point. For this see,
[Knowledge - A Very Short Introduction](r/gv7e).

But knowledge is also viewed from questioning what we know, that being, the
information we have at our disposable that informs our thinking and behaviour.
Knowledge in this sense can be understood as the scientific process; meaning,
some process of experience and thinking that leads us to a conclusion.
Theoretically, this does _not_ have to be logical or rational,
[Knowledge - A Very Short Introduction, p.61](r/gv7e). But within the field of
science, the scientific procedure (logic and rationality through observation)
are required.

[Actor-Network Theory](g/5c0r) is interesting to look at here as ANT does not
differentiate between knowledge (science, in this case) and the artefacts of
knowledge (technology or more knowledge), see [Encyclopedia of Social Theory](r/hu2q).

---

Source: no direct source, in exploration of my [ctech masters thesis](i/ip4r).

title: ‚ÄòVulkan files‚Äô leak reveals Putin‚Äôs global and domestic cyberwarfare tactics
link: [‚ÄòVulkan files‚Äô leak reveals Putin‚Äôs global and domestic cyberwarfare tactics](r/qw7o)
lead:
> *Codenamed Scan-V, it scours the internet for vulnerabilities, which are then
> stored for use in future cyber-attacks.*
body:
> *Codenamed Scan-V, it scours the internet for vulnerabilities, which are then
> stored for use in future cyber-attacks.*

> *Markov founded Vulkan (meaning volcano in English) in 2010, with Alexander
> Irzhavsky.*

> *From 2011 Vulkan received special government licences to work on classified
> military projects and state secrets. It is a mid-sized tech company, with more
> than 120 staff ‚Äì about 60 of whom are software developers.*

> *One part of Amezit is domestic-facing, allowing operatives to hijack and take

> *From 2011 Vulkan received special government licences to work on classified

> than 120 staff ‚Äì about 60 of whom are software developers.*
